Description: THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY STREAMS AND REEF FLAT SITES IN GUAM WATERSHEDS TO DETERMINE NUTRIENT LOADING AND PROVIDE THE BASIS FOR PREDICTIVE MODELS FOR DISSOLVED INORGANIC NITROGEN THRESHOLDS IN ACCORDANCE WITH GUAM'S WATER QUALITY STANDARDS. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL SAMPLE THE REEFS ADJACENT TO EACH SAMPLING SITE TO QUANTIFY THE CONDITION OF FISH,CORAL, BENTHIC, AND MACROINVERTEBRATE ASSEMBLAGES TO DETERMINE THE EXTENT TO WHICH WATER QUALITY AND/OR FISHING PRESSURE COULD PREDICT THE CONDITION OF REEF ASSEMBLAGES IN ORDER TO PRIORITIZE SITE-BASED MANAGEMENT FOR WATERSHED MANAGMENT AND PROTECTION.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $139,392. REFER TO CONDITION F REGARDING THE OMNIBUS TERRITORIES ACT AND COST SHARE (MATCH).

HAWAII'S DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES (DAR) PROPOSES TO CREATE A PROTOCOL FOR THE PERMITTING PROCESS SPECIFICALLY FOR CORAL RESTORATION PROJECTS. DEVELOPING A SCIENTIFICALLY-BASED PROTOCOL FOR CORAL RESTORATION PROJECTS WILL NOT ONLY EXPEDITE THE PERMITTING PROCESS, BUT ALSO ENSURE THAT HAWAII CORAL REEFS ARE BEING RESTORED IN A MINDFUL WAY WITH APPROPRIATE METHODS IN SUITABLE LOCATIONS.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $155,391.

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES ASSISTANCE TO BUILD CAPACITY OF CALIFORNIA WETLAND PROGRAM TO PROTECT/RESTORE VERNAL POOLS BY: 1) REMAPPING VERNAL POOL EXTENT IN CENTRAL VALLEY AND DISPLAYING THIS INFORMATION IN ECOATLAS; 2) DESIGN AND CONDUCT AN ASSESSMENT OF VERNAL POOL CONDITION FOR THE CENTRAL VALLEY USING CALIFORNIA RAPID ASSESSMENT METHOD (CRAM); AND 3) DEVELOP A HABITAT DEVELOPMENT CURVE FOR RESTORED VERNAL POOLS.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $146,390.

THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETE THE PLANNING FOR THE BAY AREA REGIONAL WETLANDS REGIONAL MONITORING PROGRAM (WRMP). THE BAY AREA WRMP IS NEEDED TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR TIDAL MARSH RESTORATION BY ENABLING THE ASSESSMENT OF WETLANDS PROJECTS TO AMBIENT CONDITIONS, ESPECIALLY AS TIDAL MARSHES ARE VULNERABLE TO SEA LEVEL RISE. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO COORDINATE AND ALIGN THE MONITORING PROGRAM WITH STATE AND FEDERAL REGULATORY PROGRAMS AND WITH OTHER REGIONAL EFFORTS TO RESTORE WETLANDS INCLUDING THE BAY RESTORATION REGULATORY INTEGRATION TEAM, CONSIDERATION OF NEW BAY FILL POLICIES, AND THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY RESTORATION AUTHORITY.   THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $244,835.

THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND KNOWLEDGE OF THE LOCATIONS, EXTENT, AND STATUS OF ISOLATED AND HEADWATER SPRINGS, SPRINGS-DEPENDENT SPECIES, AND PRIORITY WETLANDS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF KNOWN SPRING LOCATIONS AND THEIR CONDITION, IMPROVED KNOWLEDGE OF KNOWN SPRING LOCATIONS, IMPROVED WETLAND INVENTORIES AND BASELINE CONDITION ASSESSMENTS AND DATA, INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF THE STATUS OF SPRINGS- AND WETLAND-DEPENDENT SENSITIVE SPECIES, AND INCREASED AWARENESS OF WETLANDS PROGRAM.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $193,672.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.

THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE CONSERVATION FRAMEWORKS FOR 2-4 LARGE HABITAT BLOCKS IN CALIFORNIA'S CENTRAL VALLEY AND MODOC PLATEAU REGIONS.  THE APPLICANT WILL CONVENE A TECHNICAL ADVISORY WORKGROUP, IDENTIFY EXTANT VERNAL POOL HABITAT BLOCKS BY ECOREGION, DEVELOP ECOREGION PROFILES AND CONSERVATION STRATEGY FRAMEWORKS FOR EACH HABITAT BLOCK AND THEN PREPARE A FINAL REPORT TO BE SHARED AND DISSEMINATED.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $120,291.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A SUITE OF MOLECULAR (DNA-BASED) LEVEL 3 INDICATORS AND METHODS THAT DIRECTLY MEASURE STREAM ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONING IN A RAPID, COMPREHENSIVE, AND COST-EFFECTIVE MANNER. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO PROVIDE A TOOL THAT CAN BE USED TO EVALUATE POTENTIAL CAUSAL STRESSORS DUE TO NUTRIENT IMPACTS, AND TO ASSESS THE PERFORMANCE OF COMPENSATORY MITIGATION PROJECTS.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDS IN THE AMOUNT OF $149,863.

THE PROJECT INCLUDES RIPARIAN ASSESSMENT AND PRIORITIZATION TOOLS NEEDED TO SUPPORT THE PROTECTION OF RIVERS AND ASSOCIATED WETLANDS. THE RECIPIENT WILL VALIDATE THE RIPARIAN RAPID ASSESSMENT METHOD (RIPRAM) TOOL, DEVELOP AND TEST WATERSHED CONDITION ESTIMATION MODELS, DEVELOP RIPARIAN ZONE PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT GOALS, IMPROVE DECISION MAKER ACCESS TO WATERSHED CONDITION DATA/INFORMATION, AND TRACK PROGRESS TOWARDS MEETING CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA RIPARIAN PROTECTION AND ENHANCEMENT GOALS.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $249,286.

THE CHICKEN RANCH RANCHERIA OF ME-WUK INDIANS OF CALIFORNIA WANTS TO DEVELOP A WETLAND PROTECTION PROGRAM. IN ORDER TO HELP ACHIEVE THIS GOAL, THE TRIBE WILL CREATE A WETLANDS PROGRAM PLAN, BUILD STAFF CAPACITY TO DELINEATE WETLANDS, BUILD STAFF CAPACITY TO MONITOR WETLANDS, CREATE A WETLAND DELINEATION QUALITY ASSURANCE PROJECT PLAN (QAPP), CREATE A WETLAND MONITORING QAPP, CREATE A WETLAND MONITORING PLAN, AND TRANSFER RESULTS TO OTHER STAKEHOLDERS.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $29,193.

THESE FUNDS SUPPORT FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE TRIBE'S WATER POLLUTION CONTROL AND NONPOINT SOURCE CONTROL PROGRAMS. MAJOR ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: WATER QUALITY MONITORING AND ANNUAL REPORTING, FURTHER DEVELOPING THE QUALITY ASSURANCE PROJECT PLAN, SELECTING AND INSTALLING BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR WATER POLLUTION CONTROL, INCREASING STAFF KNOWLEDGE OF METHODS TO PROTECT WATER QUALITY AND CONTROL NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION, AND INFORMING THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY OF WHY AND HOW TO PROTECT WATER QUALITY.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $95,000.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP A BUENA VISTA RANCHERIA WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN USING DATA GATHERED FROM THE RANCHERIA, AND WITH INPUT AND REVIEW FROM THE TRIBE'S COMMUNITY.  THIS AWARD PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $45,000.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A FUNCTIONAL ASSESSMENT METHOD FOR STREAMS AND WETLANDS USING DNA BARCODE SEQUENCING. THIS WILL DIRECTLY MEASURE BIOLOGIC COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND CONDITION QUICKLY AND COMPREHENSIVELY, WHICH CAN BE USED TO IMPROVE THE ABILITY TO MEASURE RESTORATION SUCCESS ACROSS AQUATIC HABITATS.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $99,905.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.

TO IMPLEMENT THE CALIFORNIA WETLANDS PROGRAM PLAN WITHIN THE 9-COUNTY SF BAY AREA BY PLANNING THE BAY AREA REGIONAL WETLAND MONITORING PROGRAM. THE PRIMARY PARTNERS ARE THE REGULATORY AGENCIES RESPONSIBLE FOR TIDAL MARSH AND WATER QUALITY PROTECTION AND RESTORATION. THERE IS A NEED TO IMPROVE MONITORING EFFORTS TO ACHIEVE COST-EFFECTIVE APPROACHES IN THE LONG TERM TO ACCOUNT FOR THE LARGE PUBLIC INVESTMENT IN TIDAL MARSH RESTORATION AND THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP AND FINALIZE A PROGRAM PLAN FOR REGIONAL MONITORING.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $139,123.  PREAWARD COST APPROVED BACK TO 9/1/2017.

THIS PROJECT ASSESSES SALT MARSH VULNERABILITY AND THE IMPACTS OF SALT MARSH RETREAT ON CARBON SEQUESTRATION IN HUMBOLDT BAY, CA. IT WILL MONITOR SEDIMENT SUPPLY, MARSH ACCRETION RATES RELATED TO REMOVAL OF INVASIVE SPARTINA, AND CHARACTERIZE MARSH RETREAT RATES AND THE IMPACT ON CARBON SEQUESTRATION. INFORMATION WILL BE USED TO MANAGE WATER QUALITY AND WETLANDS IN THE ESTUARY, AND TO SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT OF A LONG TERM DREDGING PROGRAM FOR THE BENEFICIAL REUSE OF SEDIMENTS.   THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $137,500.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP GIS ANALYTICAL METHODS USING LIDAR TO MORE ACCURATELY  IDENTIFY THE LOCATION OF STREAMS AND ADJACENT STREAMSIDE CONSERVATION AREAS TO REFINE SONOMA COUNTY RIPARIAN CORRIDOR SETBACK ZONING MAPS.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES  PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUT OF $45,801.

THE PROJECT WILL VALIDATE THE EPHEMERAL STREAMS CALIFORNIA RAPID ASSESSEMENT METHOD (CRAM) MODULE, REVISE AND TRANSFER THE CALIFORNIA METHOD TO ARIZONA, AND REFINE INDICIES OF BIOLOGICAL INTEGRITY FOR EPHEMERAL STREAMS BASED ON TERRESTRIAL ARTHROPODS AND BRYOPHYTES. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE THAT THE ASSESSMENT METHODS ARE ADEQUATELY ASSESSING WETLAND CONDITION, THEREBY PROVIDING THE STATES WITH BETTER ASSESSMENT TOOLS. THIS WORK WILL SUPPORT CALIFORNIA'S WETLAND AND RIPARIAN AREA MONITORING PLAN  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING OF $235,297.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.

PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING A SPRINGS ONLINE DATABASE, CONDUCTING LEVEL 1 ASSESSMENT MAPPING OF NEVADA WETLANDS AND DEVELOPING A CONSERVATION AGREEMENT AND STRATEGY FOCUSED ON VOLUNTARY RESTORATION AND PROTECTION GUIDANCE AND STRATEGIES FOR SPRINGSNAIL SPECIES. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS FOR THE NEVADA NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM, IN COLLABORATION WITH THE DESERT RESEARCH INSTITUTE, THE NATURE CONSERVANCY AND THE SPRINGS STEWARDSHIP INSTITUTE TO DEVELOP NEVADA'S STATE WETLAND PROGRAM BY EXPANDING KNOWLEDGE OF THE LOCATION, EXTENT AND STATUS OF SPRINGS AND WETLANDS IN THE STATE.    THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $222,683.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A RESTORATION PRIORITIZATION PLAN FOR WETLANDS IN THE LAKE TAHOE BASIN, DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A BASIN-WIDE WETLAND MONITORING PLAN, AND PRODUCE A DOCUMENT DETAILING WETLAND RESTORATION AND MITIGATION QUANTITATIVE DEFINITIONS AND PERFORMANCE METRICS.  THE RECIPIENT WILL WORK WITH LOCAL AND STATE PARTNERS TO ENSURE THESE PRODUCTS ARE USED AND IMPLEMENTED CONSISTENTLY THROUGHOUT THE BASIN.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $98,625.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP A COMMON BASEMAP OF AQUATIC RESOURCES IN THE SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA. FUNDS WILL ALSO BE USED TO DEVELOP A STANDARD REGIONAL TYPOLOGY FOR AQUATIC RESOURCES IN THE DELTA, TRAIN LOCAL GEOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION SYSTEM (GIS) STAFF AND INCORPORATE DATASET INTO ECOATLAS AND REGIONAL TRACKING/MONITORING EFFORTS.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $149,980.00.  PRE-AWARD COSTS HAVE BEEN APPROVED BACK TO OCTOBER 1, 2017.
THE PROJECT WILL ASSIST THE CA COASTAL CONSERVANCY IN UNDERSTANDING SEA LEVEL RISE EFFECTS ON SALT MARSH SUSTAINABILITY AND PRIORITIZING WETLAND REST
THE PROJECT WILL ASSIST THE SANTA MONICA BAY RESTORATION AUTHORITY IN DEVELOPING STANDARIZED WETLAND MONITORING PROTOCOLS. THE PROJECT INCLUDES REVIE
TO DEVELOP PROTOCOLS TO PRIORITIZE THE 571 WATERSHEDS AND ADJACENT COASTAL WATERS FOR PROTECTION AND RESTORATION IN THE HAWAIIAN ISLANDS. THESE PROPO
THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY REGIONAL WATER QUALITY CONTROL BOARD'S (WATER BOARD) EVALUATION OF REGULATORY OPTIONS ASSOCIATED WITH
THE AQUATIC SCIENCE CENTER WILL ADVANCE STATEWIDE WETLAND PLANNING AND TRACKING OF PROJECTS IN THE WATERSHED CONTEXT TO FURTHER DEMONSTRATE AND TRANS
THIS PROJECT DEMONSTRATES THE USE OF HISTORICAL HYDROLOGY TO PRIORITIZE MULTI-BENEFIT WETLAND RESTORATION IN THE PETALUMA RIVER WATERSHED.  THIS ACTI
THIS PROJECT'S OBJECTIVE IS TO UPDATE THE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WETLANDS RECOVERY PROJECT REGIONAL STRATEBY IN ORDER TO PROTECT AND RESTORE WATERSHEDS

DESCRIPTION:
THE PURPOSE OF THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT IS TO CONNECT AND FACILITATE DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES (DLNR) AGENCIES AND PARTNERS (INCLUDING THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII AS A SUB-RECIPIENT) TO DEVELOP A PROTECTION AND RESTORATION STRATEGY FOR THE STATE'S WETLANDS OF FOCUS: ANCHIALINE POOLS AND MARSHES. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED IN FOUR PHASES: 
1.	CONVENE A STATE ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO PRIORITIZE WETLAND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES.  
2.	DEVELOP A MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT STRATEGY. 
3.	IDENTIFY REGULATORY POLICIES, APPROVALS, AND PROTECTIONS. 
4.	COMPILE AND DISTRIBUTE THE PROJECT'S OUTPUTS WIDELY AMONG PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS TO GUIDE FUTURE VOLUNTARY PROTECTION AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES. 
THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE SIGNIFICANT PROGRESS IN COORDINATION AND COLLABORATION BETWEEN DLNR DIVISIONS, SUCH AS THE DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES (DAR) AND DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE (DOFAW), AND INCREASED CAPACITY TO PROTECT AND RESTORE WETLANDS AT INCREASED RISK DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE.  

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDS IN THE AMOUNT OF $105,646.

ACTIVITIES:
TASK 1- VOLUNTARY PROTECTION AND RESTORATION: PRIORITIZE METHODS AND SITES IN THE PROTECTION AND RESTORATION STRATEGY. (HAWAII WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN PROTECTION AND RESTORATION CORE ELEMENT) 
ACTIVITY 1.1: FACILITATE INTERDIVISION COORDINATION TO IDENTIFY AND ALIGN STRATEGY PRIORITIES WITHIN A MANAGEMENT ADVISORY BOARD (TIER 2) (P 1.1). CONVENE DLNR STAFF FOR AN INTRODUCTION TO THE STRATEGIC PLANNING PROCESS, AND TO OUTLINE DIVISION PRIORITIES, CURRENT AND FUTURE PROJECTS, AND PARTNERSHIPS. 
OUTPUTS: AT LEAST 1 MEETING WITH DLNR WETLAND MANAGEMENT ADVISORY BOARD OF STAFF FROM DAR AND DOFAW, WITH STAFF FROM DIVISIONS OF CONSERVATION AND RESOURCE ENFORCEMENT, STATE PARKS, AND HISTORIC PRESERVATION TO BE DETERMINED. COMPILED SUMMARY OF PROGRAMS, PROJECTS, AND PRIORITIES.
ACTIVITY 1.2: IDENTIFY COMMUNITY PARTNERS, PRACTITIONERS, AND THEIR RESPECTIVE PRIORITIES (P 1.2). DEVELOP A LIST OF COMMUNITY PARTNERS, RESTORATION AND PROTECTION PRACTITIONERS, AND OTHER NON-DLNR ORGANIZATIONS WORKING IN PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF MARSHES AND ANCHIALINE POOLS. ENSURE REPRESENTATION OF CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS AND KUPUNA WITH TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE OF THESE WETLANDS AND RESTORATION PRACTICES (E.G. LOʻI KALO, LOKO IʻA). CONTACT THESE INDIVIDUALS AND GROUPS FOR THEIR INTEREST IN JOINING A COMMUNITY ADVISORY BOARD. CONVENE A MEETING TO INTRODUCE THE STRATEGIC PLANNING PROCESS, AND TO OUTLINE RESPECTIVE PRIORITIES, CURRENT AND FUTURE PROJECTS, AND THEIR PARTNERSHIPS. 
OUTPUTS: COMPILED SUMMARY OF PROGRAMS, PROJECTS, AND PRIORITIES; COMMUNITY ADVISORY BOARD (TIER 1) MEMBERS, TO BE DETERMINED. IDEALLY THIS GROUP WILL BE BETWEEN 10 - 20 REPRESENTATIVES OF FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES, NONPROFITS, RESEARCHERS, AND OTHERS ACTIVE IN WETLAND PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF MARSHES AND ANCHIALINE POOLS.  
ACTIVITY 1.3: CONVENE A TWO-TIERED ADVISORY BOARD (MANAGEMENT AND COMMUNITY) TO PRIORITIZE SITE SELECTION AND METHODS WITH STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES FOR PROTECTION AND RESTORATION (P 1.4; P 1.5). FOLLOWING A CONSENSUS-BUILDING APPROACH OF ALTERNATING MEETINGS BETWEEN THE MANAGEMENT (DLNR) AND COMMUNITY (NON-DLNR) ADVISORY BOARDS, THE PROJECT WILL OUTLINE ESSENTIAL COMPONENTS OF AND DEVELOP THE PROTECTION AND RESTORATION STRATEGY FOR DLNR. 
OUTPUTS: PROTECTION AND RESTORATION GOAL AND OBJECTIVES, DEFINITIONS, PRIORITY METHODS AND SITE SELECTION CRITERIA, MONITORING AND EVALUATION, SPATIAL DATA OF WETLAND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES. MEETING NOTES AND ADVISORY BOARD PARTICIPANTS. 
ACTIVITY 1.4: FINALIZE AND WIDELY DISTRIBUTE THE PROTECTION AND RESTORATION STRATEGY (P 1.4; P 4.1; P 4.4). PROJECT STAFF AND ADVISORY BOARD MEMBERS WILL DISTRIBUTE THE FINAL DRAFT OF THE STRATEGY WITHIN THEIR NETWORKS, MAKE PRESENTATIONS AND OUTREACH MATERIALS AVAILABLE PUBLICLY, AND SCHEDULE AN ANNUAL EVALUATION TO MARK PROGRESS ON AND ADAPT THE

DESCRIPTION:
THE AWARD WILL BE USED TO UPDATE GEOSPATIAL DATABASE OF AQUATIC RESOURCES AND MAP RIPARIAN AREAS IN THE RUSSIAN RIVER WATERSHED AND SONOMA COUNTY AND PROVIDE TRAINING AND PUBLIC ACCESS ON OUTPUTS.

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $174,787.  PREAWARD COSTS HAVE BEEN APPROVED BACK TO MARCH 1, 2022.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.
ACTIVITIES:
ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING CARI BASEMAP FOR RRW AND R3MP TAC REVIEW OF RRW DRAFT DATASET, TRAINING ON CAR AND WRAMP TOOLS, UPDATING ECOATLAS AND RIPZET VEGETATION AND HILLSLOPE MODULES, MAP CHANNEL EDGE FOR SONOMA COUNTY, COMPARE RIPARIAN MAPPING METHODS AND SUMMARY OF MEMORANDUM, PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS TO RIPZET OUTPUTS, AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT/PROGRESS REPORTING OF THE ABOVE TASKS.
OUTCOMES:
THE EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES INCLUDE RRQ GEOSPATIAL DATASET UPDATES, NEW DRAINAGE NETWORK MAP FOR SONOMA COUNTY, MEETING MATERIALS AND SUMMARIES, ECOATLAS UPDATE, RIPZET MODULE UPDATES TO ARCGIS PRO, RIPZET SHAPEFILES FOR RRW, GEOSPATIAL DATASET OF CHANNEL EDGE FOR SONOMA COUNTY, COMPARATIVE MAPS OF RIPARIAN AREAS BY MAPPING METHODS AND SUMMARY MEMO, RIPZET SHAPEFILES FOR RRW AND ACCESSIBLE AS A NEW RIPARIAN LAYER IN ECOATLAS, AND SEMI-ANNUAL PROJECT PROGRESS REPORTS, FINAL REPORT, AND EXECUTIVE SUMMARY. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARY IS THE PUBLIC.
SUBRECIPIENT:
ASC-SFEI WILL MANAGE THE PROJECT, INCLUDING INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL COORDINATION, PROJECT PROGRESS
REPORTING (SEMI-ANNUAL AND FINAL PROJECT REPORTS, AND 2-PAGE SUMMARY CONSISTENT WITH EPA
CONTRACT REQUIREMENTS), ACCOUNTING, AND INVOICING. ASC-SFEI WILL DEVELOP PURCHASE ORDERS FOR
CONSULTANT SERVICES FROM THE R3MP&RSQUO;S NON-STATE OR FEDERAL AGENCY SCIENCE ADVISORS AND OTHER
EXPERT SCIENTISTS TO SUPPORT THE SCIENTIFIC OVERSIGHT AND REVIEW OF PROJECT TASKS DESCRIBED ABOVE.
PROJECT BUDGETS AND EXPENDITURES WILL BE TRACKED MONTHLY BY THE PROJECT MANAGER THROUGH THE
ASC-SFEI ACCOUNTING SYSTEM AND INVOICES WILL BE SUBMITTED NOT LESS THAN QUARTERLY DEPENDING
ON THE AMOUNT OF EXPENDITURES.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT IS TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR ASSESSING WETLAND RECOVERY EFFORTS IN SUPPORTING REGIONAL WETLAND HEALTH AND RESILIENCY. SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A REGIONAL MONITORING PROGRAM FOR THE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WETLANDS RECOVERY PROJECT (WRP). 

THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $146,000.  REFER TO TERMS AND CONDITIONS.
ACTIVITIES:TASKS INCLUDE: 1- DEVELOPMENT OF PROJECT GOVERNANCE AND PRIORITIES 2- DEVELOPMENT OF WETLANDS REGIONAL PRIORITY (WRP) REGIONAL MONITORING PROGRAM 3- DEVELOPMENT OF AN EXAMPLE WRP SITE-SPECIFIC MONITORING PLAN. THE PROJECT WILL ADVANCE THE MONITORINGAND ASSESSMENT/REGULATORY/VOLUNTARY RESTORATION AND PROTECTION/WATER QUALITY STANDARDS CORE ELEMENT(S) AND THE STRATEGIC GOAL OF PROTECTING WETLANDS AND WATER QUALITY. EXPECTED BENEFICIARIES ARE STATE OF CALIFORNIA AGENCIES SUCH AS STATE WATER BOARD, FEDERAL REGULATORS, PROJECT DEVELOPERS, RESTORATION SPECIALISTS, MITIGATION BANKERS AND IN LIEU FEE SPONSORS, BECAUSE IT AIMS TO CREATE A CONSISTENT APPROACH/PROTOCOL FOR REGIONAL MONITORING. SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARD ACTIVITIES: CALIFORNIA COASTAL COMMISSION: PROVIDE REGULATORY AGENCY INSIGHT AND GUIDANCE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE REGIONAL MONITORING PROGRAM. CENTRAL COAST WETLANDS GROUP: COORDINATE WITH STATEWIDE MONITORING EFFORTS, HELP REFINE MONITORING INDICATORS, AND HELP WITH SENTINEL SITE SELECTION. SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA COASTAL WATER RESEARCH PROJECT: DEVELOP ALL COMPONENTS OF THE REGIONAL MONITORING PROGRAM AND COORDINATE INPUT FROM THE OTHER GRANTEES. THE BAY FOUNDATION: INCORPORATE PREVIOUS MONITORING INDICATORS DEVELOPED IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA INTO THE REGIONAL MONITORING PROGRAM.OUTCOMES:PRODUCTS/OUTPUT WILL BE:
1- SENTINEL SITE CRITERIA (EG SUB-REGION, WETLAND TYPE, CONDITION SCORE) AND LIST OF SELECTED SENTINEL SITES
2- LIST OF WETLAND HEALTH INDICATORS AND ASSOCIATED STATEMENT OF PROCEDURES
3- LIST OF SEA-LEVEL-RISE RESILIENCE INDICATORS AND A CONCEPTUAL MODEL LINKING RESILIENCE INDICATORS WITH WETLAND CONDITION AND DRIVERS
4- IDENTIFICATION OF MECHANISMS FOR IMPLEMENTATION, FUNDING, AND DATA MANAGEMENT 
5- CULMINATION OF PRODUCTS IN A WRP LEVEL 3 REGIONAL MONITORING PROGRAM DOCUMENT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT IS TO COLLABORATIVELY CONTINUE DEVELOPING NEVADA'S WETLAND PROGRAM BY: (I) REVISING NEVADA'S WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN (WPP), (II) DEVELOPING AN ONLINE APP TO CREATE A MORE USER-FRIENDLY, ENGAGING LEVEL 1 WETLAND ASSESSMENT TOOLBAR (WETBAR) PRODUCT, AND (III) PRODUCING ENHANCED INFORMATION ON NEVADA SPRINGS COMMUNICATED THROUGH ONLINE SERVICES AND WEBINARS AND NEW KNOWLEDGE OF SPRINGS AND SPRINGS-DEPENDENT TAXA (SDT) FROM UNDER-STUDIED REGIONS IN THE STATE. SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A REVISED WPP FOR THE STATE, AN ONLINE VERSION OF WETBAR, INFORMATION ON ADDITIONAL SPRINGS IN NEVADA DELIVERED THROUGH THE WEBSITE 'SPRINGS ONLINE,' ENHANCED FUNCTIONALITY OF SPRINGS ONLINE, WEBINARS TO PRESENT THE RESULTS, AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS FOR NEVADA SCHOOLS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A NEW NEVADA WPP, AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF KNOWN SPRING LOCATIONS AND THEIR CONDITION, IMPROVED KNOWLEDGE OF KNOWN SPRING LOCATIONS, IMPROVED WETLAND INVENTORIES

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT IS FOR THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY CONSERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION (BCDC) TO ADDRESS REGIONAL DEMANDS FOR REUSE OF SEDIMENT AND SOIL IN WETLAND RESTORATION PROJECTS TO BENEFIT SF BAY WETLANDS. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES REGULATORY AND FINANCIAL BARRIERS TO FURTHER WETLAND RESTORATION SUCCESS THROUGH THE FOLLOWING TASKS: (1) A RESULTS CHAIN ANALYSIS WHICH WILL CREATE A COALITION OF STAKEHOLDERS TO SUPPORT ADDITIONAL SEDIMENT RE-USE; (2) POLICY IMPROVEMENTS IN A SAN FRANCISCO BAY PLAN AMENDMENT; AND (3) A FINANCING STRATEGY TO SUPPORT THE USE OF SEDIMENT IN RESTORATION PROJECTS. BCDC SEEKS TO CHANGE THE BAY AREA SEDIMENT RE-USE WITH ADDITIONAL PARTNERSHIPS WITH REGULATORY AGENCIES, RESTORATION, DREDGING, AND FLOOD PROTECTION ENTITIES, ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITIES AND OTHER REGIONAL STAKEHOLDERS. PROGRESS ON THIS PROJECT BENEFITS THE REGION'S PUBLIC, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS AND ITS NATURAL RESOURCES BY RESTORING THE BAY'S WETLANDS AS A KEY CLIMATE AND RISING SEAS ADAPTATION STRATEGY AND CONSERVATION STRATEGY FOR NATIVE AND LISTED SPECIES. 

THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $151,850.ACTIVITIES:PHASE 1: SCOPING AND WORK PLAN FORMULATION; STAKEHOLDER IDENTIFICATION AND ENGAGEMENT; BACKGROUND DOCUMENT DEVELOPMENT; MULTIPLE WORKSHOPS WITH STAKEHOLDERS; DEVELOPMENT OF A FINAL ROAD MAP FOR RESTORING WETLANDS USING SEDIMENT AND SOILS FOR CLIMATE ADAPTATION. 
PHASE 2: BAY PLAN AMENDMENT PROCESS INCLUDING PUBLIC COMMENT PERIOD; BCDC COMMISSIONERS VOTE AND DOCUMENTS WOULD BE PREPARED FOR THE OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE LAW AND OFFICE OF COASTAL MANAGEMENT REVIEW. 
PHASE 3: FINANCE STRATEGY DEVELOPMENT AND PRESENTATION TO BCDC COMMISSIONERS. SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARD WITH SFBJV WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT THROUGH WORKSHOP SERIES AND TECHNICAL ANALYSIS FROM THE RESTORATION COMMUNITY.
SUBAWARD WITH SFEI WILL PROVIDE SCIENTIFIC ADVICE, TECHNICAL WRITING AND MAKE PRESENTATIONS DURING THE WORKSHOP SERIES. 
OUTCOMES:MILESTONE SCHEDULE PROVIDED IN THE WORKPLAN FOR ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASED SHORELINE PROTECTION AND IMPROVED POLICIES THAT LEAD TO INCREASED ACREAGE OF RESTORED AND RESILIENT WETLAND RESTORATION PROJECTS THROUGH THE USE OF SEDIMENT/SOIL OR RECONNECTED/REDIRECTED FLOOD SYSTEMS. THESE ACTIVITIES WILL BENEFIT THE PEOPLE OF THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA AS WELL AS SPECIES DEPENDENT ON TIDAL WETLANDS HABITAT.

THE GRANT WILL ASSIST AND IMPROVE THE NEW WETLANDS REGIONAL MONITORING PROGRAM IN PHASE 3 FOR THE BAY AREA TO BENEFIT SF BAY WETLANDS. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT ENABLES TRIBES AND COMMUNITY REPRESENTATIVES TO INFLUENCE DECISION-MAKING, ENSURE THAT TRIBAL AND COMMUNITY VALUES ARE REPRESENTED IN MONITORING, AND GUIDE DEVELOPMENT OF MONITORING PROTOCOLS AND VISUALIZATIONS THAT MEET COMMUNITY NEEDS. SPECIFIC PROJECT TASKS INCLUDE: SCIENTIFIC CONSENSUS ON INDICATORS TO MONITOR ECOSYSTEM SERVICES PROVIDED BY WETLANDS, STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES TO COLLECT AND ANALYZE DATAAND DATA COLLECTION TEMPLATES OPTIMIZED FOR COMMUNITY-BASED SCIENCEAND DATA PORTAL DASHBOARDS FEATURING A RANGE OF VISUALIZATIONS TAILORED TO COMMUNITY INTERESTSAND A REGULATORY NEEDS ASSESSMENT, COST ASSESSMENT, AND REGULATORY ENGAGEMENT ROADMAPAND AND A LONG TERM FUNDING STRATEGY FOR THE WRMP. PROGRESS ON THIS PROJECT BENEFITS THE REGION&RSQUOANDS PUBLIC, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS AND ITS NATURAL RESOURCES BY RESTORING THE BAY&RSQUOANDS WETLANDS AS A KEY CLIMATE AND SEA LEVEL RISE ADAPTATION STRATEGY FOR NATIVE AND LISTED SPECIES.

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $177,202.  PREAWARD COSTS HAVE BEEN APPROVED BACK TO JANUARY 1, 2022.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.
ACTIVITIES:
THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE THE FOLLOWING TASKS: ASSEMBLE AN ADVISORY COMMITTEE OF REPS FROM ALL RELEVANT MANAGEMENT AGENCIES; DEVELOP A SAMPLE FRAME AND PROBABILISTIC SAMPLE SCHEME; WORK WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO CONDUCT REGIONAL-SCALE SAV SURVEY AND DEVELOP AND OPEN ACCESS DATABASE; BUILD A CONDITION ASSESSMENT TOOL TO INTERPRET THE ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONING OF THE SAV; VALIDATE THE FUNCTIONING OF SAV BEDS AS HABITAT FOR NEKTON. 
OUTCOMES:
THESE TASKS WILL ALLOW APPLICANT TO CONDUCT FUTURE SURVEYS WHILE ALSO PROVIDING SCIENTIFICALLY ROBUST DATA INTERPRETATION AND COMMUNICATION TOOLS. THE STATED GOAL OF THE 2017-2022 CALIFORNIA WETLANDS PROTECTION PLAN IS TO 'INCREASE THE ABUNDANCE, CONDITION AND DIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA'S WETLANDS RIPARIAN AREAS, AND SUSTAIN AND ENHANCE THE DELIVERY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES'. THE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT WOULD BE THE CA AGENCIES RESPONSIBLE FOR EELGRASS WETLANDS; THEY CURRENTLY LACK THE TOOLS TO ASSESS CONDITION AND EVALUATE ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION. 


SUBRECIPIENT:
THE PRIMARY ROLE OF THE SUBCONTRACTORS WILL BE PERFORMING THE SCUBA-BASED DATA COLLECTION ON THE SAV BEDS. THEY WILL BE A MIX OF SCCWRP'S CO-PIS FROM CAL STATE LONG BEACH AND LOCAL CONSULTANTS WHO REGULARLY WORK IN THE REGION&RSQUO;S SAV BEDS.

DESCRIPTION:
THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR THE MID AMERICA REGIONAL COUNCIL TO DEVELOP A FEASIBILITY STUDY TO EVALUATE AND PILOT NEW CONSERVATION FINANCE TOOLS FOR THE METRO AREA. THE PROJECT WILL ACCELERATE GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE IMPLEMENTATION AND INFORM HOW METRO PARTNERS INCREASE INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY TO IMPLEMENT AND MANAGE LARGE-SCALE PROJECTS ON THE GROUND. 
ACTIVITIES:
THE PROJECT INCLUDES AN ASSESSMENT OF THE VIABILITY OF EXISTING AND POTENTIAL FUNDING RESOURCES, THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SET OF AT LEAST TEN ACTIONABLE SCALABLE PROJECTS, DEVELOPMENT OF AT LEAST ONE PILOT PROJECT PLAN, AND STAKEHOLDER AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. 
OUTCOMES:
THE OUTPUTS ARE STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT SUCH AS SEVEN PROJECT ADVISORY COMMITTEE MEETINGS, THREE FINANCIAL TASK FORCE MEETINGS, AND THREE COMMUNITY WORKSHOPS, COMPLETION OF FEASIBILITY STUDY INCLUDING INVENTORY ASSESSMENT OF BEST PRACTICES, FUNDING MATRIX, PROJECT CRITERIA, AND IMPLEMENTATION RECOMMENDATIONS, DEVELOPMENT OF A WETLANDS PROJECT DATABASE, AND ONE PILOT PROJECT PLAN. THE OUTCOMES ARE INCREASED QUALITY, FUNCTIONALITY AND CONNECTIVITY OF EXISTING WETLANDS WITHIN A MATRIX OF SUSTAINABLE LAND USE, IMPROVED PROCESSES AND COMMUNITY COMMITMENT FOR WETLAND PROTECTION AND RESTORATION, AND INCREASED STAKEHOLDER AND DECISIONMAKER UNDERSTANDING OF FUNDING MECHANISMS TO SUPPORT WETLAND RESTORATION. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE RECIPIENT AS WELL AS THE CITY OF KANSAS CITY AND ITS RESIDENTS.
SUBRECIPIENT:
NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.

DESCRIPTION:
THE PURPOSE OF THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT IS TO ASSESS THE LARGE WETLANDS ESTABLISHED ALONG THE SHORELINES OF A SUBSET OF LARGE FEDERAL RESERVOIRS LOCATED IN KANSAS. 
ACTIVITIES:
THE PROJECT INCLUDES IDENTIFYING WETLANDS ASSOCIATED WITH MAJOR RESERVOIRS AND IMPOUNDMENTS, SELECTING A SUBSET FOR FIELD EVALUATION, CREATING A FIELD DATABASE AND ANALYZING THE DATA.
OUTCOMES:
THE OUTPUTS ARE A SHORELINE WETLAND INVENTORY FOR THE STUDY RESERVOIRS, A MAP OF NON-SHORELINE POTENTIAL WETLAND AREAS WITHIN THE FLOOD POOLS OF THE STUDY RESERVOIRS, LAKE INUNDATION FREQUENCY OF THE MAPPED WETLANDS, AND WATER QUALITY INFORMATION FOR THE RESERVOIRS AND ASSOCIATED WETLANDS. THE OUTCOMES ARE INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF WETLAND WATER AND SEDIMENT QUALITY, BIOLOGICAL CONDITION, AND RETENTION TIME ON THE REST OF THE RESERVOIR WATER BODY, INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF IMPACTS OF WIND AND WATER FLUCTUATION ON WETLAND FUNCTIONING, AND ENHANCED KNOWLEDGE BASE ABOUT KANSAS' WETLAND SYSTEMS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE RECIPIENT AS WELL AS THE STATE OF KANSAS.
SUBRECIPIENT:
THEY WILL WORK ON THE FOLLOWING GOALS: IDENTIFY AND INVENTORY WETLANDS ASSOCIATED WITH MAJOR RESERVOIRS AND IMPOUNDMENTS IN KANSAS, EXAMINE WIND AND WATER DATA FOR THOSE RESERVOIRS, AND DO FIELD SAMPLING OF SITES.

THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI IN COLUMBIA TO INVESTIGATE FLOODPLAIN MORPHOLOGY AND ASSOCIATED GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION OF WETLAND FEATURES TO DEVELOP A GIS METHODOLOGY FOR CHARACTERIZING THE SUITABILITY OF SITES IN FLOODPLAINS FOR WETLAND ESTABLISHMENT WITH APPLICABILITY TO DIFFERENT SIZE STREAMS AND FLOODPLAINS.

DESCRIPTION:
THE PURPOSE OF THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING FOR THE MISSOURI DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES TO ESTABLISH A SET OF REFERENCE WETLANDS IN MISSOURI.

 IT INCLUDES FIELD MONITORING OF BIOLOGICAL AND WATER QUALITY DATA AT EXISTING SITES, EXPLORING ADOPTION OF A VEGETATION MULTIMETRIC INDEX, AND CONDUCTING DESKTOP AND FIELD VERIFICATION.
OUTCOMES:
THE OUTPUTS ARE A SET OF REFERENCE WETLANDS IN TARGET AREAS, DEVELOPMENT OF A METHODOLOGY TO IDENTIFY LIKELY REFERENCE WETLANDS, COLLECTION OF WATER QUALITY AND BIOLOGICAL DATA FOR REFERENCE WETLANDS, IMPACTED WETLANDS, AND INTERMEDIATE WETLANDS TO CAPTURE THE RANGE OF CONDITIONS IN THESE SYSTEMS, AND UPDATED MISSOURI WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN. THE OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF WATER QUALITY IN MISSOURI WETLANDS, INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF HIGHEST ATTAINABLE USES OF MISSOURI WETLANDS, AND CONSIDERATION OF THE DEVELOPMENT OF WETLAND WATER QUALITY STANDARDS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE RECIPIENT AS WELL AS THE STATE OF MISSOURI.

THE UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING (UW) IS PROPOSING TO DEVELOP A WEBSITE THAT WILL PROVIDE USERS WITH ACCESS TO INFORMATION AND DATA ABOUT WETLANDS IN THE STATE OF WYOMING. UW HAS COLLECTED CONSIDERABLE INFORMATION ABOUT WYOMING WETLANDS THROUGH WORK UNDER PREVIOUS EPA WETLAND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AND OTHER GRANTS. THIS INFORMATION ABOUT WETLANDS (THEIR FEATURES, DISTRIBUTION, AND CONDITION) AND ABOUT METHODS FOR ASSESSING THEM IS USEFUL FOR MANAGING WETLANDS BUT PRESENTLY IS AVAILABLE ONLY IN PROJECT REPORTS. THIS PROJECT INVOLVES TAKING THIS PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED INFORMATION AND INCORPORATING IT INTO UW'S WYOMING NATURAL DIVERSITY DATABASE (WYNDD). A NEW, WETLANDS-SPECIFIC WEBSITE (MICROSITE) WILL BE DEVELOPED WITHIN THE EXISTING WYNDD WEBSITE TO MAKE WETLANDS INFORMATION READILY ACCESSIBLE. THE NEW WETLANDS WEBSITE ALSO WILL LINK TO INFORMATION ON WEBSITES OF OTHER ORGANIZATIONS, AND THUS WILL BE A HUB FOR INFORMATION ABOUT THE STATE'S WETLANDS. THE NEW WETLANDS WEBSITE WILL BE MAINTAI

THE UTAH DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY, DIVISION OF WATER QUALITY (UDWQ) IS PROPOSING TO EVALUATE THE CONDITION, FUNCTION, AND BENEFICIAL USE ATTAINMENT OF UTAH'S WETLANDS. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE MONITORING OF IMPOUNDED AND FRINGE WETLANDS AROUND GREAT SALT LAKE AND ESTABLISHMENT OF A HIGH-FREQUENCY MONITORING NETWORK TO TRACK WATER QUALITY PROCESSES IN THE WETLANDS AROUND GREAT SALT LAKE. THE OUTPUTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE A MODEL OF HYDROPERIOD AND WATER QUALITY DYNAMICS IN GREAT SALT LAKE WETLANDS, A FINALIZED GREAT SALT LAKE IMPOUNDED WETLAND ASSESSMENT TOOL, AND A DRAFT ASSESSMENT METHOD FOR THE FRINGE CLASS OF GREAT SALT LAKE WETLANDS.

THE UTAH GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (UGS) IS PROPOSING TO DEVELOP A DETAILED PROFILE OF WETLANDS IN THE CENTRAL BASIN, INCLUDING A DESCRIPTION OF REFERENCE CONDITIONS FOR DIFFERENT WETLAND CLASSES AND ESTIMATES OF WETLAND CONDITION, FUNCTION, AND COMMON DISTURBANCES ACROSS THE REGION. THIS OBJECTIVE WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH THREE MAJOR ACTIVITIES AND SUPPORTING OUTREACH TASKS: 1) CREATION OF NEW TOOLS TO USE WITH AN EXISTING WETLAND ASSESSMENT PROTOCOL, 2) SYNTHESIS OF EXISTING DATA COLLECTED BY THE UTAH GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (UGS) FROM FIVE DIFFERENT PROJECTS IN THE CENTRAL BASIN TO DETERMINE A CLASSIFICATION SYSTEM AND TO SCREEN THE EXISTING DATA FOR POTENTIAL HIGH-QUALITY REFERENCE SITES WITHIN EACH CLASS, AND 3) FIELD SURVEYS. OUTPUTS WILL INCLUDE NEW MODULES FOR THE UTAH RAPID ASSESSMENT PROTOCOL (URAP), ECOLOGICAL DESCRIPTIONS AND REFERENCE CONDITION METRICS FOR COMMON WETLAND CLASSES IN THE CENTRAL BASIN, AND A FINAL REPORT DESCRIBING METHODS AND RESULTS. THE UTAH GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (UGS) IS PROPOSING TO CREATE A SPATIAL DATASET OF WETLANDS AND THEIR POTENTIAL FUNCTIONS IN CACHE COUNTY AND TO ENHANCE THE ACCESSIBILITY OF WETLAND DATA VIA THE UGS WETLAND MAPPER APPLICATION. UGS WILL MAP WETLANDS AND RIPARIAN AREAS IN A PORTION OF CACHE COUNTY USING ESTABLISHED PRACTICES AND APPLY LANDSCAPE POSITION, LANDFORM, WATER FLOW PATH, AND WATERBODY TYPE (LLWW) ATTRIBUTES TO THE NEW SPATIAL DATA TO PROVIDE BETTER INFORMATION ON THE HYDROGEOMORPHIC SETTING OF WETLANDS. UGS WILL CONDUCT A LITERATURE REVIEW, HOST STAKEHOLDER MEETINGS, AND WORK WITH REGIONAL MAPPING PARTNERS TO DEVELOP A CROSSWALK BETWEEN MAPPED WETLAND ATTRIBUTES AND WETLAND FUNCTIONS. UGS WILL ALSO CONDUCT SEVERAL OUTREACH ACTIVITIES TO IMPROVE THE USE OF EXISTING WETLAND DATA. UGS WILL DEVELOP LANDSCAPE PROFILES FOR MAJOR WATERSHEDS IN UTAH BY SUMMARIZING EXISTING DATA SUCH AS WETLAND EXTENT, CLASS, POTENTIAL LANDSCAPE STRESS, AND OWNERSHIP. THE COLORADO NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM AT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY WILL UPDATE NATIONAL WETLAND INVENTORY MAPPING AND CONDUCT FIELD-BASED WETLAND ASSESSMENTS AT 15-20 SITES IN THE GREATER AURORA AREA. WATER QUALITY DATA WILL ALSO BE COLLECTED AT THESE SITES IN PARTNERSHIP WITH CITY OF AURORA STAFF. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DOCUMENT THE LOCATION AND CONDITION OF WETLANDS IN AURORA, AND TO CREATE USEFUL PRODUCTS FOR LOCAL LAND MANAGERS, LAND OWNERS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN THE CITY OF AURORA, COLORADO.

THE COLORADO NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM AT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY WILL BE THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT RECIPIENT. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS WORK IS TO REVISE COLORADO'S WETLAND AND RIPARIAN VEGETATION CLASSIFICATION; REVISE COLORADO'S FLORISTIC QUALITY ASSESSMENT (FQA); CREATE A COLORADO WETLAND AND STREAM RESTORATION DATABASE; AND UPDATE AND EXPAND THE COLORADO WETLANDS APP.

THE COLORADO NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM AT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY WILL BE THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT RECIPIENT. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS WORK IS TO PROVIDE STAKEHOLDERS, INCLUDING PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, WITH SCIENTIFICALLY VALID DATA ON THE CONDITION, RARITY, LOCATION, ACRES, AND TYPES OF WETLANDS WITHIN THE ROARING FORK WATERSHED. THE SUPPORTING TASKS INCLUDE: 1. FORM AN ADVISORY COMMITTEE OF FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS; 2. MAP FENS (VULNERABLE WETLANDS); 3. CONDUCT FIELD SURVEYS OF TARGETED WETLAND AREAS; 4. PROCESS RESULTS OF FIELD AND FEN MAPPING DATA; 5. PREPARE A FINAL REPORT, AND 6. PRESENT RESULTS TO STAKEHOLDERS AND PUBLIC.

THE WYOMING GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT (WGFD) IN COLLABORATION WITH DUCKS UNLIMITED (DU) WILL DEVELOP AND PROMOTE TOOLS AND RESOURCES TO HELP STATE AND LOCAL NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS INTEGRATE WETLAND CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT INTO EXISTING PROGRAMS. WORK WILL INCLUDE: (1) IMPLEMENTING AND SHOWCASING WET MEADOW RESTORATION TECHNIQUES FOCUSED ON AGRICULTURAL LANDS; (2) PLANNING A WETLANDS TRAINING FOR LOCAL DECISION MAKERS; (3) OFFERING WETLAND TECHNICAL EXPERTISE IN WATERSHED PLANNING TO INCREASE PARTICIPATION IN VOLUNTARY RESTORATION; (4) DEVELOPING WETLAND MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES FOR PRODUCING DESIRED PLANT COMMUNITIES IN DROUGHT PRONE SYSTEMS; AND, (5) EXPLORING THE FEASIBILITY OF USING BEAVER DAM ANALOG (BDA) STRUCTURES AND CONTRIBUTING TO IMPROVED PERMITTING GUIDELINES.

THROUGH THIS GRANT MONTANA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (MDEQ) WILL CONDUCT THREE PROJECTS TO FURTHER DEVELOP AND REFINE MDEQ'S COMPREHENSIVE STATE WETLAND PROGRAM. THE THREE PROJECTS ARE: 1) DEVELOPING WETLAND ASSESSMENT COMPONENTS FOR ENHANCED TMDL AND NON-POINT SOURCE COORDINATION; 2) REVITALIZING AND RESTRUCTURING THE MONTANA WETLAND COUNCIL; AND, 3) REVISING MDEQS WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN. PRODUCTS FROM THESE PROJECTS INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO A DRAFT 2020 WATER QUALITY INTEGRATED REPORT WITH WETLANDS INCORPORATED, WETLANDS INCORPORATED INTO ENHANCED TMDL AND NONPOINT SOURCE SUPPORT PLANNING DOCUMENTS, A RESTRUCTURED AND STABLE MONTANA WETLAND COUNCIL, AND AN UPDATED 10-YEAR WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN.

THREE AFFILIATED TRIBES (TAT) OF THE FORT BERTHOLD INDIAN RESERVATION (FBIR) WILL COMPLETE THE FOLLOWING TASKS UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT: ESTABLISH GOALS AND OBJECTIVES;  ASSEMBLE GEODATABASES; DEVELOP WETLAND DATA; COMPLETE WETLAND FUNCTIONAL ASSESSMENTS; WETLAND TOOL DESIGN AND LAYOUT;  CREATE WETLAND SCIENCE CURRICULUM; IDENTIFY TAT  STAKEHOLDERS; STAKEHOLDER OUTREACH; DEVELOP A WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN AND PROTOCOLS. NORTH DAKOTA STATE UNIVERSITY (NDSU) IS PROPOSING TO DEVELOP A TOOL THAT WILL PROVIDE USERS WITH DATA ABOUT PRAIRIE POTHOLE WETLAND RESTORATION. THE TOOL WILL BE DESIGNED TO ASSESS SUCCESS OF RESTORATION OF PPR WETLANDS IN TERMS OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES IN RELATION TO TIME SINCE RESTORATION. NDSU'S PAST RESEARCH HAS SHOWN THAT RESTORED WETLANDS DIFFER FROM NATURAL WETLANDS IN BIOGEOCHEMISTRY. IN THE PROPOSED STUDY NDSU WILL ASSESS BIOGEOCHEMISTRY, VEGETATION AND INVERTEBRATES AS MEASURES OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. NDSU DOES EXPECT THAT THERE WILL BE CHARACTERISTIC DIFFERENCES, SUCH AS ORGANIC MATTER (OM) CONTENT AND OM-BOUND ELEMENT CONCENTRATIONS WILL BE LOWER, OTHER ELEMENTS WILL BE HIGHER, VEGETATION AND INVERTEBRATE DENSITY, DIVERSITY AND FUNCTIONAL TRAITS TO BE LOWER THAN THAT OF NATURAL WETLANDS. NDSU DOES EXPECT OLDER RESTORED WETLANDS TO BE MORE LIKE NATURAL WETLANDS THAN YOUNGER ONES. TASKS WILL INCLUDE SITE SELECTION, SAMPLING AND ANALYSIS, DATA ANALYSIS, AND (4) PREPARATION OF REPO

THE MONTANA NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM (MTNHP) HAS BEEN ASSESSING AND MONITORING WETLANDS FOR NEARLY TWO DECADES. THEIR EARLY PROJECTS WERE GENERALLY RESTRICTED TO AREAS CHOSEN BY PARTNER FUNDERS (CROWE AND KUDRAY 2003, JONES 2003A AND 2003B, JEAN ET AL. 2002, JONES AND HENDRICKS 2002). HOWEVER, WITH THE INCREASING AVAILABILITY OF GIS, AND THE HELP OF WPDG FUNDING, THEY GRADUALLY MOVED FROM 'COMMISSIONED' SURVEYS OF WETLAND RESOURCES TO PROBABILISTIC SURVEYS OF ENTIRE BASINS (NEWLON ET AL. 2013, NEWLON 2012, VANCE ET AL. 2012, MCINTYRE ET AL. 2011). THEY ALSO CONDUCTED INVESTIGATIONS ON FOCUSED TOPICS SUCH AS HEADWATER WETLANDS (VANCE ET AL. 2015) OR INVASIVE SPECIES (WESTFALL AND VANCE 2017, TOBALSKE AND VANCE 2017). THESE BROADER PROJECTS GENERATED LARGE QUANTITIES OF INFORMATION, AND HAVE BEEN WELL RECEIVED BY THEIR PARTNERS. HOWEVER, ONLY A HANDFUL HAVE OFFERED SUPPORT FOR ON-THE-GROUND DECISION MAKING AT THE LOCAL LEVEL (HAHN ET AL. 2016, OWEN 2014, LUNA ET AL. 2012). THIS GRANT PRO

IN RECENT DECADES, CNHP AND ITS MANY PARTNERS IN GOVERNMENT, ACADEMIA, AND THE PRIVATE SECTOR HAVE GREATLY EXPANDED THE SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION FOR COLORADOS WETLANDS, LEADING TO INCREASED RECOGNITION OF THE ROLE WETLANDS PLAY PROVIDING ESSENTIAL ECOSYSTEM SERVICES SUCH AS FLOOD RETENTION, WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENT, AND WILDLIFE HABITAT. EPA WETLAND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT GRANTS (WPDGS) HAVE PROVIDED FUNDING FOR A SUBSTANTIAL PORTION OF THIS RESEARCH. HOWEVER, SIGNIFICANT GAPS REMAIN, PARTICULARLY REGARDING THE CONDITION OF WETLANDS ACROSS THE STATE. AN UPCOMING CNHP REPORT ON THE STATE OF COLORADO WETLANDS DETAILS THE EXTENT AND DISTRIBUTION OF WETLANDS ACROSS COLORADO BASED ON THE MOST RECENT NATIONAL WETLAND INVENTORY (NWI) MAPPING (LEMLY ET AL. IN PROGRESS), INCLUDING WETLAND ACRES BY TYPE, LAND OWNERSHIP, ECOREGION, AND MAJOR RIVER BASIN. THE REPORT PAINTS A CLEAR PICTURE OF WHERE WETLANDS ARE CONCENTRATED AND WHERE THEY ARE LESS COMMON. HOWEVER, THE REPORT STOPS SHORT OF FULLY DESCRIBING THE STATE OF COLORADO WETLANDS BECAUSE WE LACK SUFFICIENT DATA TO DISCUSS THE CONDITION OF WETLANDS ACROSS THE STATE AS A WHOLE. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, CNHP WILL CARRY OUT THREE MAJOR OBJECTIVES CRITICAL TO THE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT AND PROTECTION OF COLORADOS WETLANDS: 1. CARRYING OUT A STATEWIDE INTENSIFICATION OF THE NATIONAL WETLAND CONDITION ASSESSMENT (NWCA) FOR COLORADO 2. EXPANDING THE COLORADO WETLAND PLOTS DATABASE TO INCLUDE ALL NEW NWCA DATA FOR COLORADO AND ADDITIONAL DATA CONTRIBUTED BY PARTNER AGENCIES AND SCIENTISTS 3. UPDATING THE COLORADO WETLANDS APP WITH ADDITIONAL SPECIES AND FEATURES

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CHARACTERIZE THE ATTRIBUTES OF HISTORIC HYDRIC (SATURATED) SOILS AND HOW THEY CAN BE LEVERAGED TO ENHANCE WATER QUALITY AND ECOLOGICAL HEALTH OF FLOODPLAIN AND WETLAND RESTORATIONS. CURRENTLY, NO GUIDANCE EXISTS ON THE USE OF HISTORIC HYDRIC SOILS IN ECOSYSTEM RESTORATIONS, AND THEY ARE TYPICALLY REMOVED FROM RESTORATION SITES. IN THE ABSENCE OF SUCH GUIDANCE, WE MAY BE LOSING VALUABLE NATIVE MICROBIOME AND SEEDBANKS AT RESTORATION SITES. THE PROJECT WILL FUND PERSONNEL, TRAVEL, AND ANALYTICAL COSTS. OUTPUTS INCLUDE ASSESSMENT CRITERIA AND GUIDANCE ON USE OF HISTORIC HYDRIC SOILS IN WETLAND RESTORATIONS AS WELL AS TRAINING, TOOLS, AND EDUCATION MATERIAL FOR WETLAND RESTORATION PRACTITIONERS AND AGENCIES. PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE RESIDENTS OF DELAWARE AND WETLAND SCIENTISTS NATIONALLY. THERE ARE NO SUB-AWARDS INCLUDED IN THIS PROJECT. 

FEDERAL FUNDS OF $114,278 ARE CONTINGENT UPON AVAILABILITY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO FACILITATE COORDINATION OF ALL LEVELS OF GOVERNMENT AND EDUCATE THE PUBLIC TO PROVIDE PROTECTION FOR HIGH VALUE AQUATIC RESOURCES IN VIRGINIA. THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON SUPPORTING DECISION-MAKING BY ENHANCEMENT OF THE WETLANDS CONDITION ASSESSMENT TOOL (WETCAT) TOOL BY DELIVERING THE FOLLOWING OUTPUTS: 1) GENERATING AN AUTOMATED FORM TO STREAMLINE PERMITTING DECISIONS REGARDING INTERAGENCY REVIEW TEAM MITIGATION SITING CRITERION AND SITE SELECTION, 2) ENABLING THE USE OF THE VIRGINIA FLORISTIC QUALITY ASSESSMENT CALCULATOR AND LINKAGE TO WETLAND POLYGONS, 3) INCORPORATING ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE DEMOGRAPHICS TO INFORM WETLAND RESOURCE DECISION MAKING, 4) CALIBRATING WETLAND STRESSORS WITH SURROUNDING LANDCOVER AND WETLAND CONDITION, 5) EMPOWERING WETLAND RESOURCE INFORMATION EXCHANGE BETWEEN VIRGINIA AND NORTH CAROLINA IN THE SHARED WATERWAYS OF THE ALBEMARLE - PAMLICO WATERSHED, AND 6) EXPANDING SOCIAL MEDIA AND WEB TRACKING METRIC CAPABILITIES OF WETCAT

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE DECISION-MAKING CAPACITY, LEADING TO LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF COASTAL WETLANDS UNDER SEA LEVEL RISE. THERE ARE TWO CRITICAL COMPONENTS OF THE DECISION-MAKING PROCESS: 1) A DETAILED AND RECENT INVENTORY OF THE EXTENT AND COMPOSITION OF COASTAL WETLANDS, AND 2) AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONS SUPPORTED BY COASTAL WETLANDS. THIS PROJECT WILL FUND STAFF, SUPPLIES, TRAVEL, AND A SUB-AWARD TO WILLIAM AND MARY CENTER FOR CONSERVATION BIOLOGY TO:  I) DEVELOP A ROUTINELY-REPEATABLE MONITORING METHOD FOR ASSESSING CHANGES TO MARSH COMMUNITIES, II) CONDUCT AN EXPANDED INVESTIGATION OF THE USE OF NEWLY MIGRATED MARSH BY MARSH-OBLIGATE SPECIES, AND III) DEVELOP A FRAMEWORK FOR INCORPORATING CHANGES IDENTIFIED THROUGH MONITORING INTO RECENTLY DEVELOPED VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENTS. OUTPUTS INCLUDE LITERATURE REVIEWS, INUNDATION DURATION MAPPING, METHOD DEVELOPMENT, FIELD, DRONE VEGETATION SURVEYS, AND SATELLITE SURVEYS, BIRD AND SOIL SURVEYS, NEWSLE

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE SHORELINE STABILIZATION DECISIONS IN MARYLAND TO PROTECT MD'S 3,000 MILES OF COASTLINES THAT ARE VULNERABLE TO THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE.   FUNDING WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT PERSONNEL, TRAVEL, SUPPLIES, AND A SUBAWARD TO THE VIRGINIA INSTITUTE OF MARINE SCIENCES (VIMS) TO UPDATE THE MD SHORELINE INVENTORIES, AND WEB-BASED MAPS SHOWING SUITABILITY OF SHORELINES FOR VARIOUS TYPES OF STABILIZATION PRACTICES FOR THE REMAINING 9 COUNTIES OF MARYLAND THAT HAVE NOT BEEN COMPLETED. OUTPUTS WILL INCLUDE A MAPPING TOOL AND RELATED EDUCATIONAL EVENTS AND TRAINING FOR LOCALITIES AND THE PUBLIC REGARDING THE AVAILABILITY OF THE MAPPING TOOL. ALSO, A WAIVER PROCESS FOR SUITABLE OPTIONS FOR LIVING SHORELINE APPROACHES WILL BE PLANNED. THIS FOLLOWS UP ON PREVIOUS GRANTS AND WILL COMPLETE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A MD STATEWIDE TOOL FOR SHORELINE STABILIZATION GUIDANCE. PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE RESIDENTS OF MARYLAND.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD DELAWARE'S PROGRAM CAPACITY TO RESTORE AND RECOVER TIDAL AQUATIC RESOURCES THROUGH RESEARCH, PARTNERSHIP, DEMONSTRATION, AND FRESHWATER RESOURCES THROUGH MONITORING AND POLICY BUILDING. THIS PROJECT ALSO PLANS TO EXPAND KNOWLEDGE OF ALL DELAWARE WETLANDS THROUGH OUTREACH AND EDUCATION. FUNDING FOR THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT STAFF, SUPPLIES, TRAVEL, CONTRACTUAL WORK (FOR CONFERENCE VENUE, TO ANCHOR QEA FOR DREDGING AND SEDIMENT SAMPLING), AND A SUBAWARD TO THE KENT CONSERVATION DISTRICT STAFF SUPPORT.  OUTPUTS INCLUDE A 'REPORT CARD' SUMMARIZING WETLAND CONDITION ASSESSMENT FOR THE POCOMOKE WATERSHED, A CONFERENCE, EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND PRESENTATIONS FOR THE WETLAND SCIENCE COMMUNITY AND THE PUBLIC, A DEMONSTRATION OF A RESTORATION PROJECT RESULTING IN A VEGETATED TIDAL WETLAND AND NATIVE HABITAT, AND A MARSH MIGRATION MODEL. ALL PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE A SUMMARY REPORT OF ACCOMPLISHMENTS. PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE RESIDENTS OF DELAWARE.

THIS PROJECT WILL FUND STAFFING, SUPPLIES, TRAVEL, AND FUNDING TO PA'S NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM, WESTERN PA CONSERVATION. OUTPUTS INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT AND FINALIZATION OF A STRATEGIC WETLAND PLAN (SWP) FOR LANDS MANAGED BY THE PA DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND NATURAL RESOURCES (DCNR) WHICH INCLUDES173,000 ACRES OF WETLANDS; DEVELOPMENT OF PROTOCOLS AND TRAINING MATERIALS TO ASSESS THE AQUATIC RESOURCES; DATA COLLECTION FROM FIELD WORK AND ASSESSMENTS; AND THE CREATION OF OUTREACH MATERIALS FOR THE PUBLIC. NO STRATEGIC PLAN FOR WETLANDS CURRENTLY EXISTS FOR THESE LANDS. BY IDENTIFYING THE AQUATIC RESOURCES WHICH HAVE HIGH CONSERVATION VALUE WETLANDS ON DCNR LANDS, THIS PROJECT WILL ASSIST IN THE PROTECTION OF CRITICAL HABITAT FOR PA'S RARE WILDLIFE AND PLANT SPECIES. THESE FUNDS WILL BE USED TO FUND STAFF POSITIONS OVER TWO YEARS AND TO COVER TRAVEL EXPENSES AND FIELD SUPPLIES IN ORDER TO ADDRESS BARRIERS TO THE IMPROVEMENT OF FUNCTIONAL PERFORMANCE OF WETLAND RESTORATION. FIVE MAIN TASKS ARE PROPOSED TO DEVELOP A NEW PROTOCOL THAT APPROPRIATELY MEASURES WETLAND PROJECT FUNCTION AND PROGRESSION AND CREATES A VOLUNTARY RESTORATION WORKGROUP CONSISTING OF LOCAL PROFESSIONALS. THE PROPOSAL INCLUDES AN INTERAGENCY AGREEMENT WITH PARTNERS SUCH AS THE ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS (COE), THE NATURE CONSERVANCY (TNC), FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS), DUCKS UNLIMITED, AND THE DELAWARE NON-POINT SOURCE PROGRAM (NPS). THE INTENDED OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE WETLAND RESTORATION FUNCTION/ECOSYSTEM SERVICES.

DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA'S DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT (DOEE) PROJECT ENTITLED 'DEVELOPMENT OF DISTRICT STRATEGIC 3-TO-5-YEAR WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN AND DEVELOPMENT OF A COMPREHENSIVE WETLAND ASSESSMENT AND MONITORING PROGRAM' CONSISTS OF TWO MAIN OBJECTIVES: 1) DEVELOP A STRATEGIC 3-5-YEAR DISTRICT WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN (WPP) AND (2) DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE WETLAND MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT PROGRAM. THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND NATURAL RESOURCES (PADCNR) IS FUNDING STAFF POSITIONS OVER THREE YEARS, TRAVEL EXPENSES, AND FIELD SUPPLIES TO FURTHER DEVELOP AND REFINE THE PA AQUATIC PLANT COMMUNITY PREDICTOR TOOL AND TO WORK WITH PARTNERS ON A CURRENT PROCESS-BASED AQUATIC WETLAND RESTORATION PROJECT IN THE LITTLE ARNOT RUN WATERSHED. THROUGH MONITORING OF PRE- AND POST-RESTORATION CONDITIONS AT THE WATERSHED LEVEL, THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE PA DEP WITH THE FINDINGS FROM THIS PROJECT TO HELP INFORM AND DEVELOP PROCESS-BASED STANDARDS AND SUCCESS MEASURES. PADCNR WILL WORK THROUGH THE PA NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM (PNHP) TO CONDUCT FIELD WORK, DATA COMPILATION, AND ANALYSIS. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS PA'S WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN AND WILL ENHANCE THE SUCCESS OF WETLAND RESTORATION AND MITIGATION PROJECTS IN PA.

THIS PROJECT FUNDS MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT (MDE) TO ENTER INTO A SUBAWARD AGREEMENT WITH THE VIRGINIA INSTITUTE OF MARINE SCIENCE (VIMS) AS WELL AS A PERCENT OF MDE NATURAL RESOURCES AND TIDAL WETLAND PROGRAM MANAGER PERSONNEL TIME. THE FUNDS WILL ALSO COVER SUPPLIES AND TRAVEL.  THE PROPOSAL INCLUDES A SHORELINE INVENTORY, AND DATA ANALYSES TO INFORM MAPPING AND OTHER TOOLS TO NAME A FEW TASKS. PRIMARILY, MDE WILL BE EXPANDING UPON THE MARYLAND LIVING SHORELINE SUITABILITY MODEL TO COVER AN ADDITIONAL FOUR COUNTIES. THIS WILL STREAMLINE THE PROCESS OF APPLYING FOR A LIVING SHORELINE WAIVER AS WELL AS HELP MAKE THE DECISIONS MORE STANDARD AND UNIFORM.

VIRGINIA INSTITUTE OF MARINE SCIENCE (VIMS) COSTAL WETLAND PROJECT WILL SUPPORT VIMS PERSONNEL TIME, SUPPLIES, AND TRAVEL, WITH ABOUT 25% OF THE FUNDS DEDICATED TO A SUBAWARD. FIVE TASKS ARE PROPOSED TO 1) IDENTIFY AREAS OF RECENT MARSH MIGRATION THAT COINCIDE WITH MARSH OBLIGATE BREEDING BIRD HABITAT, 2) ASSESS CHANGES IN ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION IN MARSHES IMPACTED BY RAPID RATES OF SEA LEVEL RISE, 3) INITIATE DEVELOPMENT OF AN ASSESSMENT TOOL TO IDENTIFY AREAS WITH A HIGH LIKELIHOOD TO SUPPORT MARSH OBLIGATE BREEDERS IN THE FUTURE, 4) ASSESS MULTIPLE PLACE-BASED BENEFITS OF SPECIFIC WETLANDS TO INCLUDE HABITAT AND WATER QUALITY BENEFITS, AND 5) CONDUCT AND IMPROVE OUTREACH TO WETLAND PRACTITIONERS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

WEST VIRGINIA UNIVERSITY REQUESTS FUNDS FOR STAFF, TRAVEL, FIELD SUPPLIES AND CONTRACT TO GATHER AND ANALYZE MONITORING DATA AND OTHER INFORMATION THAT WILL BECOME THE BASIS OF WATER QUALITY STANDARDS IN WV. OUTPUTS FROM THE STUDY WILL BECOME THE BASIS FOR DEVELOPING STRATEGIES THAT WILL INFORM FUTURE ENHANCEMENT AND MITIGATION ACTIONS ON RESILIENCE DESIGN SO THAT MARSHES MAINTAIN THEIR TERRESTRIAL CARBON SEQUESTRATION FUNCTION. RESULTS FROM THE STUDY WILL ALSO BE USED FOR TESTING FUTURE ADAPTABILITY OF MARSHES TO CLIMATE CHANGE. THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT METHODS TO INCREASE THE RESILIENCE OF NEW YORK CITY'S SALT MARSHES TO SEA-LEVEL RISE AND ASSOCIATED STRESSORS BY BUILDING OFF RECOMMENDATIONS FROM PREVIOUS STUDIES THAT IDENTIFIED OUR MOST VULNERABLE WETLANDS. THESE METHODS WILL USE UPDATED AND TARGETED DESKTOP AND FIELD ASSESSMENTS TO EVALUATE AND REFINE PILOT SALT MARSH RESTORATION TECHNIQUES AND IMPROVE SELECTION METHODS FOR IDENTIFYING PRIORITY SITES WITHIN OUR MOST VULNERABLE MARSHES TO RESTORE LOST OR DEGRADING WETLANDS AND MIGRATION PATHWAYS. THE FINAL PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE PROTOCOLS, TABULAR AND SPATIAL DATA, AND FINAL REPORTS COMMUNICATING FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT..

THIS GRANT PROVIDES FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK TO REFINE ITS CURRENT ASSESSMENT METHODOLOGY  AND ASSESS THE STATUS AND CONDITION OF WETLANDS IN THE NEW YORK CITY WATER SUPPLY BASIN AND NEW YORK STATE. PROJECT GOALS ARE THE REFINEMENT OF WETLAND FUNCTIONAL ASSESSMENT PROTOCOLS, DEVELOPMENT OF LANDSCAPE-LEVEL FUNCTIONAL ASSESSMENT METRICS THAT CAN SUPPORT RAPID ON-THE-GROUND FUNCTIONAL ASSESSMENT AND EVALUATE THE CONTRIBUTION OF POLLINATORS TO WETLAND CONDITION AND FUNCTION. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH COLLABORATING WITH THE NEW YORK CITY DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION FOR WETLAND SAMPLING, POLLINATOR SAMPLING, AND EVALUATING ASSESSMENT METHODOLOGIES.

THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT WILL FUND A PROJECT TO CONTINUE THE WORK OF BARNEGAT BAY PARTNERSHIP AND THE PARTNERSHIP FOR THE DELAWARE ESTUARY WHICH ESTABLISHED THE MID-ATLANTIC COASTAL WETLANDS ASSESSMENT PROGRAM TO MONITOR WETLAND CONDITIONS AND ASSESS THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND OTHER STRESSORS. PROPOSED WORK WILL BUILD UPON ONGOING WORK BY USING STUDIES, EXPERIMENTS, RAPID STORM-RESPONSE MONITORING, AND DRONE MAPPING TO QUANTIFY HYDROLOGICAL AND METEOROLOGICAL DRIVERS OF INUNDATION IN COASTAL WETLANDS.

THE RECIPIENT WILL IDENTIFY POTENTIAL WETLAND RESTORATION SITES ON LANDS OF THE ONEIDA INDIAN NATION, DELINEATE SELECTED SITES, DRAFT AND DESIGN A WETLAND RESTORATION PLAN FOR THE SITES, AND RECOMMEND POST-RESTORATION TRACKING MEASURES.

THIS GRANT AGREEMENT WILL FUND THE NEW JERSEY DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION'S NJDEP'S, PROJECT TO DEVELOP A MITIGATION TECHNICAL MANUAL WITH MONITORING GUIDANCE FOR COMPENSATORY MITIGATION PROJECTS WHICH WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THE MITIGATION TECHNICAL MANUAL WILL COMPILE CURRENT GUIDANCE DOCUMENTS, MANUALS AND STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES CURRENTLY AVAILABLE FOR MITIGATION AND HOUSE THEM INTO ONE COMPREHENSIVE TECHNICAL MANUAL. IN ADDITION, THE MANUAL WILL ASSIST THE NJDEP IN DEVELOPING A STANDARDIZED APPROACH TO MONITORING, INCLUDING THE USE OF ECOREGIONAL FLORISTIC QUALITY ASSESSMENT TOOLS, THAT WILL ENABLE THE NJDEP TO MORE ACCURATELY IDENTIFY PATTERNS OF SUCCESS AND/OR FAILURES OF COMPENSATORY MITIGATION SITES. THE DEVELOPMENT OF THIS MANUAL WILL ALSO ENABLE THE NJDEP TO UPDATE ITS GUIDANCE TO ENSURE THAT THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE AND MITIGATION PRACTICES ARE BEING UTILIZED WITHIN NEW JERSEY.

THIS GRANT PROVIDES FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO THE NEW JERSEY DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, NJDEP, TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT TO COMPLETE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A COASTAL ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION AND ADAPTATION PLAN, CERAP, THAT WILL IDENTIFY PRIORITY AREAS FOR ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION PROJECTS IN THE COASTAL ZONE. THE CERAP WILL IDENTIFY AREAS OF NJ'S COASTAL ZONE MOST APPROPRIATE FOR FUTURE RESTORATION, ENHANCEMENT, OR PRESERVATION PROJECTS THAT WILL PRODUCE THE LARGEST NET CARBON SEQUESTRATION, ECOSYSTEM HEALTH AND COMMUNITY RESILIENCE VALUE. SINCE MULTIPLE NJDEP PROGRAMS IMPLEMENT VARIOUS ELEMENTS OF THE WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN THAT INFLUENCE COASTAL ECOLOGICAL RESOURCES, AN INTERNAL RESOURCE TEAM WILL BE CREATED TO OVERSEE THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE CERAP. A PUBLICLYAVAILABLE,WEB-BASED TOOL WITH PRIORITY AREA MAPPING, DATA AND TREND INFORMATION WILL BE DEVELOPED.

IN NEW JERSEY, THE EASTERN KINGSNAKE IS LISTED AS A SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN BECAUSE IT IS VULNERABLE TO MULTIPLE THREATS, IS POTENTIALLY DECLINING, AND ITS DISTRIBUTION AND POPULATION STATUS ARE NOT KNOWN. ALTHOUGH KINGSNAKES USE WETLANDS FOR OVERWINTERING, THE SPECIFIC WETLAND HABITAT TYPES NEEDED FOR HIBERNATION HAVE NOT BEEN DOCUMENTED. THE GRANTEE WILL USE RADIO TELEMETRY TO DETERMINE WETLAND HABITAT USE AND NESTING SITES OF THE EASTERN KINGSNAKE. RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY WILL BE USED TO EVALUATE WETLAND HABITAT VALUE AND THE ADEQUACY OF UPLAND BUFFERS THAT PROTECT THOSE WETLANDS.

NJSEA WILL MEASURE INDICATORS OF MARSH RESILIENCE TO IDENTIFY MARSHES IN THE HACKENSACK MEADOWLANDS THAT HAVE THE GREATEST CHANCE OF PERSISTING UNDER FUTURE SEA-LEVEL RISE (SLR). DELIVERABLES INCLUDE A NEW TIDAL DATUM DATASET, DIGITAL ELEVATION MAPS, MARSH EDGE MORPHOLOGY MAPS AND HYPERSPECTRAL IMAGERY SHOWING CHANGES IN LAND COVER AND HABITAT TYPE AS WELL AS THE STRENGTH IN CARBON SEQUESTRATION ASSOCIATED WITH THE DIFFERENT VEGETATION ASSEMBLAGES. OUTCOMES FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDE BETTER INFORMED, DATA DRIVEN DECISIONS BY COASTAL MANAGERS, WETLAND PRACTITIONERS AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS THAT WILL LEAD TO THE PERSISTENCE OF MORE WETLANDS AND BETTER-QUALITY WETLANDS UNDER CONDITIONS OF ACCELERATED SLR.

NEW HAMPSHIRE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES (NH DES) WILL CONTINUE TO DEVELOP A WETLAND MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT PROGRAM THAT CAN BE USED TO

THE IDEA FOR THE RESEARCH PROPOSED HERE ORIGINATED FROM DISCUSSIONS BETWEEN DR. MARINUS OTTE (NORTH DAKOTA STATE UNIVERSITY, NDSU), DR. DONNA JACOB (HOUSTON ENGINEERING INC, HEI), AND MR. AARON LARSEN (NORTH DAKOTA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY, NDDEQ) ABOUT WHAT INFORMATION RELATING TO WATER QUALITY AND WETLANDS WAS LACKING AND NEEDED TO BE ADDRESSED WITH THE HIGHEST PRIORITY IN NORTH DAKOTA. THE STATE HAS LOST AT LEAST 45% OF ITS WETLANDS1, BUT IT IS AS HIGH AS 90% IN OTHER REGIONS2,3,4, AND LOSS OF WETLANDS IS CONTINUING IN THE US AND AROUND THE WORLD5. AS A RESULT, AN INCALCULABLE VALUE OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, SUCH AS SEDIMENT AND NUTRIENT RETENTION AND HYDROLOGICAL BUFFERING HAVE BEEN LOST6. HOWEVER, IT IS ALSO RECOGNIZED THAT CONSTRUCTION OF NEW WETLANDS CAN OFFSET LOSSES &NDASHAND THE TREND IN THE US OVER THE PERIOD OF 2004-2009 SHOWED NO DISCERNIBLE LOSS IN FRESHWATER WETLANDS, MAINLY BECAUSE CONSTRUCTION OF NEW WETLANDS OFFSET LOSSES OF NATURAL WETLANDS TO AGRICULTURAL, INDUSTRIAL AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT5. A PROBLEM IDENTIFIED AS NEEDING HIGHEST PRIORITY IN NORTH DAKOTA IS REDUCTION OF SEDIMENTS AND NUTRIENT LOADING (&LSQUOANDLOADS&RSQUOAND) TO 303(D)-LISTED WATERSHEDS7, MANY INCLUDING RESERVOIRS. MOST OF THE RESERVOIRS WERE CREATED TO REDUCE DOWNSTREAM FLOODING AND AS DRINKING WATER SUPPLY AND TO SUPPORT RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES. AN APPROACH OF INTEREST TO NORTH DAKOTA WOULD BE TO INCORPORATE CONSTRUCTED WETLANDS INTO IMPACTED WATERSHEDS WITH A VIEW TO LOWER LOADS. THIS WOULD ALSO HAVE ADDED BENEFITS IN TERMS OF OTHER ECOSYSTEM SERVICES PROVIDED BY WETLANDS, SUCH AS PROVISION OF HABITATS AND HYDROLOGICAL BUFFERING. IT IS WELL KNOWN THAT WETLANDS ARE VERY EFFECTIVE IN REMOVING SEDIMENTS AND NUTRIENTS FROM WATER8, 9, 10, AND GUIDANCE ON HOW TO INCORPORATE WETLANDS INTO SYSTEMS TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY HAS BEEN IN EXISTENCE FOR DECADES, ALSO FROM THE US EPA11. THE MAIN QUESTION THAT THE PROPOSED PROJECT AIMS TO ANSWER IS: CAN WETLANDS BE CONSTRUCTED WITHIN 303(D)-LISTED WATERSHEDS IN NORTH DAKOTA TO SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE TOTAL MAXIMUM DAILY LOADS (TMDLS) TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY?
THE IDEA TO INCORPORATE CONSTRUCTED WETLANDS IN THE LANDSCAPE TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY OF ENTIRE WATERSHEDS IS NOT NEW12. A GOOD EXAMPLE OF INTEGRATION OF CONSTRUCTED WETLANDS INTO A SMALL WATERSHED IS THAT OF THE ANNE VALLEY PROJECT ON INTEGRATED CONSTRUCTED WETLANDS IN IRELAND13, WHICH WAS INITIATED IN THE 1990S14. AN EXAMPLE ALSO EXISTS FROM NORTH DAKOTA, WHERE WETLANDS WERE CONSTRUCTED IN THE BOWMAN-HALEY RESERVOIR WATERSHED IN CONJUNCTION WITH BUY-INS FROM LANDOWNERS TO THE CONSERVATION RESERVE PROGRAM, AND WHERE LOADS WERE REDUCED SUCCESSFULLY15. A MORE RECENT EXAMPLE IS PROVIDED BY FRIENDSOFRESERVOIRS.COM IN THEIR GUIDANCE ON USE OF WETLANDS FOR MITIGATION OF EUTROPHICATION16, WHICH INCLUDES AN EXAMPLE FROM A WATERSHED IN NEBRASKA. ANOTHER EXAMPLE OF RESTORATION AND CONSTRUCTION OF WETLANDS IN A WATERSHED, IN THIS CASE PRIMARILY FOR HYDROLOGICAL REASONS, IS THE TONGUE RIVER PROJECT IN NORTHEASTERN ND17. HOWEVER, WHILE GUIDELINES EXIST ABOUT HOW TO DESIGN AND SIZE WETLANDS TO REDUCE POLLUTANT CONCENTRATIONS IN SPECIFIC WASTE WATERS18, NO STUDIES HAVE BEEN REPORTED TO ANSWER THE QUESTION HOW MUCH WETLAND (SIZE, DEPTH, DESIGN) WOULD BE NEEDED TO REDUCE THE LOADS OF ENTIRE WATERSHEDS TO BELOW ACCEPTABLE THRESHOLDS OVER LONG PERIODS OF TIME, ABSENT ANY OTHER MITIGATION MEASURES AND CHANGES IN LAND USES WITHIN THE WATERSHED. IN OTHER WORDS, IS IT POSSIBLE TO DRASTICALLY IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF A WATERSHED IF ONLY THE AREA OF WETLANDS WOULD BE INCREASED? THIS IS OF IMPORTANCE, NOT JUST FOR NORTH DAKOTA, BUT FOR THE ENTIRE US AND BEYOND, BECAUSE IT WILL DETERMINE THE LIMITS OF CONSTRUCTING WETLANDS FOR WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENT OF WATERSHEDS. ARE THERE ANY SITUATIONS WHERE CONSTRUCTION OF WETLANDS SUFFICES TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY WITHIN WATERSHEDS OR ARE CHANGES IN LAND USES NECESSARY AS WELL IN MOST CASES? THROUGH THIS PROJECT THE COLORADO NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM (CNHP), IN PARTNERSHIP WITH BOULDER COUNTY AND PROJECT STAKEHOLDERS, WILL GATHER BASELINE DATASETS ON GROUNDWATER-DEPENDENT WETLANDS AT MULTIPLE SCALES THROUGHOUT THE COLORADO LOWER FOOTHILLS AND PLAINS WITH A TARGETED MAPPING AND CONDITION ASSESSMENT, RESULTING IN A SUMMARY UNDERSTANDING OF GROUNDWATER-DEPENDENT ECOSYSTEM (GDE) WETLAND COMPOSITION AND ECOLOGICAL IMPORTANCE THROUGHOUT THE PLAINS. THE PROJECT WILL CREATE AN ECOSYSTEM MAP LAYER, REFINED WETLAND ASSESSMENT METHODS, A DATA SYNTHESIS ON GDE WETLAND COMPOSITION THROUGHOUT THE STUDY AREA, GDE-SPECIFIC BMPS, AND A SUMMARY REPORT.

THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS WETLANDS IN THE MONTANE REGION OF UTAH, DEFINED HERE AS AREAS WITHIN THE SOUTHERN ROCKIES AND WASATCH AND UINTA MOUNTAINS LEVEL III ECOREGIONS (OMERNIK, 1987). UGS AND UTAH DIVISION OF WATER QUALITY (UDWQ) HAVE A TWO-PHASE PLAN FOR MONITORING WETLANDS IN THE STATE WHEREBY UGS FIRST COLLECTS BASELINE DATA IN AN ECOREGION, DETERMINES AN APPROPRIATE CLASSIFICATION SCHEME, AND CHARACTERIZES HIGH-QUALITY REFERENCE SITES, AND THEN UDWQ USES THAT DATA TO SELECT WETLAND TARGETS FOR MORE INTENSIVE SAMPLING AND TO DEVELOP APPROPRIATE BENEFICIAL USE CLASSES (MENUZ AND DOWNARD, 2017).
OUR PROPOSED ASSESSMENT OF MONTANE WETLANDS WILL BE CONDUCTED IN THREE PARTS. FIRST, WE WILL CREATE A SINGLE DATASET THAT COMBINES WETLAND DATA FROM SEVERAL DATASETS TO MORE ACCURATELY DESCRIBES MONTANE WETLAND TYPE AND DISTRIBUTION. WE WILL REVIEW THE ACCURACY OF EXISTING DATASETS SUCH AS THE NATIONAL WETLAND INVENTORY (NWI), NATIONAL LAND COVER DATABASE (NLCD), UTAH DIVISION OF WATER RESOURCES&RSQUOAND WATER RELATED LAND USE (WRLU), AND VEGETATION AND FEN MAPPING FROM THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE (USFS) USING A COMBINATION OF REMOTE SENSING AND FIELD WORK. WE WILL ALSO EVALUATE WHETHER ACCURACY CAN BE IMPROVED BY USING A COMBINATION OF EXISTING DATA. FOR EXAMPLE, NLCD HAS INACCURACIES INHERENT TO REMOTE SENSINGAND ACCURACY MAY BE IMPROVED BY IDENTIFYING OVERLAP BETWEEN NLCD WETLANDS AND AREAS WITH HYDRIC SOILS OR AREAS WITH LOW SLOPE AND HIGH RUNOFF IDENTIFIED BY THE COMPOUND TOPOGRAPHIC INDEX (HORVATH AND OTHERS, 2018). MUCH OF THE NWI DATA IN THE STUDY AREA WERE PRODUCED USING IMAGERY COLLECTED 40 YEARS AGO AND MAY NOT CAPTURE WETLAND LOSS ASSOCIATED WITH RECENT DEVELOPMENTAND ACCURACY MAY BE IMPROVED BY REMOVING WETLANDS THAT OVERLAP DEVELOPED POLYGONS IN THE WRLU LAYER. AFTER INITIAL EVALUATION OF THE STRENGTHS AND WEAKNESSES OF EACH DATASET, WE WILL RANDOMLY SELECT POINTS WITHIN EACH LAYER AND EVALUATE EACH POINT USING A DESKTOP EVALUATION OF AERIAL IMAGERY AND SUPPLEMENTAL LAYERS TO DETERMINE WHETHER EACH POINT IS IN FACT WETLAND. DESKTOP EVALUATION WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED WITH FIELD EVALUATION TO BOTH TRAIN IMAGE INTERPRETERS AND VALIDATE RESULTS. EVALUATIONS WILL BE STRATIFIED BY LEVEL IV ECOREGIONS BECAUSE PREVIOUS WORK HAS FOUND DIFFERENCES IN MAPPING ACCURACY BY ECOREGION (MENUZ AND SEMPLER, 2018). AFTER THE ACCURACY ASSESSMENT, WE WILL COMPILE THE MOST ACCURATE DATA INTO A SINGLE DATASET. THIS DATASET WILL INCLUDE INFORMATION ABOUT THE SOURCE DATA ASSOCIATED WITH EACH FEATURE AND A CONFIDENCE LEVEL ASSIGNED BASED ON THE RESULTS OF THE ACCURACY ASSESSMENT. THE COMPILED DATASET WILL GUIDE THE UPCOMING URAP ASSESSMENTS AND WILL BE PUBLISHED ON THE UGS UTAH WETLANDS APPLICATION (HTTPS://GEOLOGY.UTAH.GOV/APPS/WETLANDS/INDEX.HTML).
THE SECOND PART OF THE PROJECT CONSISTS OF WETLAND FIELD ASSESSMENTS USING THE UTAH RAPID ASSESSMENT PROCEDURE (URAP), A WETLAND ASSESSMENT PROTOCOL DEVELOPED BY UGS THAT HAS BEEN APPLIED TO OTHER MONTANE WETLANDS IN THE STATE (MENUZ AND OTHERS, 2016AAND MENUZ AND OTHERS 2016BAND MENUZ AND SEMPLER, 2018). PROBABILISTIC SURVEYS AT RANDOMLY SELECTED SITES WILL BE FOCUSED ON THE LOWER ELEVATION PORTIONS OF THE STUDY AREA, THE MOUNTAIN VALLEYS LEVEL IV ECOREGION, WHERE STRESSORS TEND TO BE HIGHER. SOME PROBABILISTIC AND TARGETED SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED ACROSS THE ENTIRE MONTANE STUDY AREA TO ALLOW US TO CHARACTERIZE HIGH QUALITY REFERENCE SITES IN EACH ECOREGION. SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED ACROSS THE ENTIRE STUDY AREA EXCEPT THE JORDAN AND WEBER HUC6 WATERSHEDS, WHERE UGS PREVIOUSLY CONDUCTED WETLAND FIELD ASSESSMENT PROJECTS BETWEEN 2014 AND 2016. DATA WILL BE ANALYZED TO ESTIMATE WETLAND CONDITION, POTENTIAL FUNCTION, AND EXTENT AND SEVERITY OF STRESSORS AND TO DESCRIBE HIGH QUALITY REFERENCE CONDITION FOR COMMON WETLAND TYPES IN THE MOUNTAIN VALLEYS.
THE FINAL COMPONENT OF THIS PROJECT IS THE MOST CRITICAL&MDASHANDPRODUCING HIGH QUALITY OUTPUTS AND ENSURING THAT THOSE OUTPUTS ARE

THE UGS PROPOSES DEVELOPING GUIDANCE MATERIAL AND ENHANCING COLLABORATION WITH EXTERNAL ORGANIZATIONS TO IMPROVE DATA CONSISTENCY. GUIDANCE MATERIAL WILL BE DEVELOPED BY CREATING DOCUMENTS ESTABLISHING CONVENTIONS AND GUIDANCE ON CHALLENGING SITUATIONS. WE WILL ALSO ENHANCE COLLABORATION WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS MAPPING IN UTAH BY SHARING THE NEWLY CREATED GUIDANCE MATERIAL, ORGANIZING REGULAR MEETINGS TO DISCUSS ONGOING MAPPING ISSUES, AND REVIEWING SMALL SECTIONS OF EACH OTHER'S DATA. THE UGS WILL CONDUCT THESE ACTIVITIES WHILE WORKING ON A NEW WETLAND MAPPING PROJECT FOR THE UTAH LAKE PROJECT AREA.
THE UTAH LAKE PROJECT AREA IS AN IDEAL TARGET FOR NEW WETLAND MAPPING. WETLANDS IN MOST OF THE AREA WERE MAPPED IN THE 1980S AND 1990S, AND IT IS AN AREA WITH HIGH RATES OF RECENT AND PROJECTED FUTURE GROWTH; THE POPULATION NEARLY DOUBLED BETWEEN 2000 AND 2019 (KEM C. GARDNER POLICY INSTITUTE, 2010 AND 2019) AND IS PROJECTED TO ABOUT DOUBLE AGAIN BY 2045 (KEM C. GARDNER POLICY INSTITUTE,

THE OBJECTIVE OF THE WORK PROPOSED HERE IS TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF UTAH'S WETLANDS BY COMPLETING TWO TASKS THAT BUILD ON AND REFINE PREVIOUS WORK ON GSL WETLAND MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT AND WETLAND WATER QUALITY STANDARD DEVELOPMENT FOR UTAH. THE FIRST TASK WE ARE PROPOSING IS TO BRING THE BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMISTRY DATA GATHERED IN WETLANDS AS FAR BACK AS 2004 INTO A SINGLE, CONSISTENT DATA STRUCTURE IN A PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE FORMAT. THE SECOND TASK IS TO COMPLETE A PROBABILISTIC SURVEY OF PLAYA AND MUDFLAT WETLANDS AROUND GSL AND USE THAT DATA IN CONJUNCTION WITH OTHER WETLAND DATA TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE STATE OF UTAH'S INTEGRATED REPORT ON THE CONDITION OF GSL WETLANDS. THE RESULTS OF THE PLAYA AND MUDFLAT SURVEY WILL ALSO BE INCORPORATED INTO THE EXISTING GSL WETLAND ASSESSMENT TOOL THAT HAS BEEN DEVELOPED IN PREVIOUS WPDG PROJECTS SO THAT THE TOOL ADDRESSES ALL MAJOR BIOLOGICAL WETLAND CLASSES AROUND GSL.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO DEVELOP A GUIDEBOOK TO COMMON WETLAND PLANTS IN UTAH'S CENTRAL BASIN. THE GUIDEBOOK WILL BE MODELED AFTER THE POCKET SERIES DEVELOPED BY CNHP (CULVER, 2018) AND WILL PROVIDE DETAILED INFORMATION ON APPROXIMATELY 150 TO 200 COMMON PLANT SPECIES IN WETLANDS IN THE WESTERN HALF OF UTAH. THE BOOK WILL INCLUDE A PREFACE DESCRIBING CENTRAL BASIN WETLANDS AND HOW TO USE THE BOOK, BUT THE BULK OF THE BOOK WILL BE MADE UP OF SPECIES PROFILE PAGES. EACH PROFILE PAGE WILL INCLUDE AT LEAST THREE ILLUSTRATIONS OR PHOTOGRAPHS, TECHNICAL CHARACTERISTICS USED FOR IDENTIFICATION, SIMILAR SPECIES WITH DISTINGUISHING CHARACTERISTICS, AND NOTES ON HABITAT AND ECOLOGY. EACH PAGE WILL ALSO INCLUDE THE WETLAND INDICATOR STATUS FOR THE ARID WEST, NATIVE STATUS, DURATION, AND COEFFICIENT OF CONSERVATISM VALUE (C-VALUE). C-VALUES ARE VALUES ASSIGNED TO SPECIES THAT INDICATE THEIR DEGREE OF ASSOCIATION WITH DISTURBED VERSUS PRISTINE HABITATS. CNHP WILL ASSIST UGS WITH THIS PR

THE PROJECTS AND ACTIVITIES ADDRESS IN THIS GRANT PROPOSAL WORK TO ACHIEVE THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OUTLINED IN OUR STATE WETLAND PLAN (SWP) THROUGH DIRECT MDEQ ACTIONS IDENTIFIED IN OUR WPP. THIS PROPOSAL ADDRESSES THE PROGRAM BUILDING ACTIVITIES MDEQ WILL UNDERTAKE TO INCREASE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF MDEQS WETLAND PROGRAM AND THE MONTANA WETLAND COUNCIL (MWC). MDEQ PROPOSES TO DO THIS THROUGH THE CONTINUED INTEGRATION OF WETLANDS IN CLEAN WATER ACT AND MONTANA WATER QUALITY ACT PROGRAMS; EFFECTIVE LEADERSHIP AND GUIDANCE OF THE MONTANA WETLAND COUNCIL; INCORPORATING WETLANDS AS WASTERS OF THE STATE, AND BETTER UNDERSTANDING THE LOSS AND MITIGATION OF WETLANDS IN MONTANA.

THROUGH THIS PROJECT UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY, IN COLLABORATION WITH STATE WETLAND MANAGERS, WILL CARRY OUT A WETLAND RESTORATION DEMONSTRATION PROJECT FOR GREAT SALT LAKE (GSL) WETLANDS. THE MAIN TASK WILL BE TO ADDRESS KEY UNCERTAINTIES THAT LIMIT REVEGETATION, SPECIFICALLY TO DETERMINE WHICH NATIVE SPECIES HAVE HIGH PERFORMANCE ACROSS HYDROLOGIC AND SALINITY GRADIENTS AND BEST OUTCOMPETE INVASIVE PHRAGMITES, AND WHICH REVEGETATION APPROACHES (SEEDS, PLUGS, SOD MATS) LEAD TO THE GREATEST PERFORMANCE ACROSS ENVIRONMENTS. THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE REVEGETATION TOOLS TO INCREASE ACREAGE AND IMPROVE GSL WETLAND RESTORATION SUSTAINABILITY, INCLUDING A COST-BENEFIT ANALYSIS OF REVEGETATION TOOLS, A DECISION TREE FOR MANAGERS TO GUIDE REVEGETATION DECISION-MAKING, TRAINING MATERIALS, AND EXTENSION REPORTS.

THREE AFFILIATED TRIBES (TAT) WOULD LIKE TO ADVANCE AND REFINE THE CURRENT WETLAND PROGRAM TO INCLUDE A MORE COMPREHENSIVE SET OF OBJECTIVES USING THE CORE ELEMENTS SUGGESTED BY THE U.S. ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA). THIS WILL ENABLE THE TAT ENVIRONMENTAL DIVISION TO THOROUGHLY ASSESS THE CONDITION AND HEALTH OF WETLAND RESOURCES AT A WATERSHED AND FIELD LEVELAND ENHANCE AND APPLY APPROPRIATE ASSESSMENT METHODOLOGIESAND AND COOPERATE WITH ADJACENT LANDOWNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS TO CONTINUE TO DEVELOP A PROGRAM TO RESTORE, MAINTAIN AND MONITOR WETLAND RESOURCES ON TRIBAL LANDS. BUILDING ON THE EXISTING WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN, THE TAT ENVIRONMENTAL DIVISION INTENDS TO DESIGN THE PROCESSES AND POLICIES THAT WILL ALLOW THEM TO ASSESS, MONITOR, CONTROL, AND PROTECT THE HEALTH OF RESERVATION WETLAND RESOURCES AND INCREASE TAT ENVIRONMENTAL DIVISION STAFF KNOWLEDGE OF WETLAND MANAGEMENT. COMPLETION OF PROJECT TASKS WILL IMPROVE THE TAT ENVIRONMENTAL DIVISIONS EXISTING WETLAND PROGRAM AND WATER QUALITY PROGRAM BY DEVELOPING CORE ELEMENTS IDENTIFIED BY THE EPA. MAIN TASKS TO ACCOMPLISH THIS OBJECTIVE INCLUDE: IDENTIFY APPROPRIATE ASSESSMENT AND MONITORING STRATEGIES TO DETERMINE WETLAND CONDITIONAND SELECT HIGH FUNCTIONING WETLAND RESOURCES FOR PROTECTIONAND IDENTIFY DEGRADED WETLAND RESOURCES FOR ENHANCEMENT AND/OR RESTORATIONAND APPLY TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE WHEN EVALUATING WETLAND FUNCTIONAND AND ENGAGE AND COOPERATE WITH LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS AND LANDOWNERS TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY BY INCREASING THE PROTECTION, ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION OF WETLAND RESOURCES.

THIS PROPOSAL BUILDS ON THE WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN &LDQUOANDCREATING COMPREHENSIVE WETLAND/RIPARIAN MAPPING, TOOLS AND SCIENCE-BASED INFORMATION FOR MONTANA AND THE WEST,&RDQUOAND SUBMITTED TO THE EPA BY THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA/MONTANA NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM (MTNHP) IN APRIL 2020.  AS ANTICIPATED IN THAT PLAN, THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA AND THE MONTANA STATE LIBRARY HAVE AGREED TO REVISE THE ORGANIZATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THE MTNHP, WITH INFORMATION SERVICES STAFF WHO MANAGE DATABASES BECOMING EMPLOYEES OF THE LIBRARY, AND SCIENCE STAFF  (WHICH INCLUDES ALL ECOLOGY AND WETLAND MAPPING STAFF WHO HAVE BEEN INVOLVED IN THE WPDG WORK) REMAINING WITH THE UNIVERSITY. ECOLOGY STAFF WILL BUILD ON THEIR EXPERIENCE AND PAST SUCCESSES TO CONTINUE DEVELOPMENT OF A ROBUST WETLAND PROGRAM, WHICH WILL NOW BE HOUSED IN THE O&RSQUOANDCONNOR CENTER FOR THE ROCKY MOUNTAIN WEST. THE UNIVERSITY-BASED PROGRAM WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE LIBRARY BASED MTNHP INFORMATION SERVICES STAFF TO ENSURE THAT DATA CAN BE MADE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH MTNHP&RSQUOANDS DATABASES, FOLLOWING THE SAME DATA SUBMISSION PROCEDURES USED BY OTHER AGENCIES (E.G. BLM, MT-FWP). HOWEVER, WHILE MTNHP HAS A STATUTORY MANDATE TO DISSEMINATE OBSERVATION DATA, THERE IS NO SIMILAR MANDATE TO HOUSE OR DISSEMINATE INTERPRETIVE PRODUCTS (REPORTS, VALUE-ADDED ANALYSES, HANDBOOKS, USER GUIDES). THEREFORE, PART OF THIS PROPOSAL WILL INVOLVE BUILDING CAPACITY TO HOST RESOURCES ON UM WEBSITES AND DATA SHARING PLATFORMS.
OVERALL, THE REORGANIZATION OFFERS AN OPPORTUNITY TO DEVELOP AN EVEN MORE HIGHLY-RESPECTED WETLAND PROGRAM THAT CAPITALIZES ON THE RESOURCES AND REPUTATION OF ITS UNIVERSITY BASE TO WORK WITH MULTIPLE COMMUNITIES OF INTEREST, INCLUDING ADVOCACY GROUPS WHEN APPROPRIATE, TO ACTIVELY PROMOTE WETLAND CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION IN MONTANA AND REGION 8. TO THIS END, THIS PROPOSAL HAS FIVE MAIN ACTIONS, DRAWN FROM ELEMENTS OF THE 2020-2025 WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN:

1.	BUILD A REGIONALLY RESPECTED STAFF WITH A PARTICULAR FOCUS ON LOTIC AND LENTIC SYSTEMS.
2.	CREATE FIELD GUIDES (ONLINE AND PRINT) TO SUPPORT IDENTIFICATION OF WETLAND AND RIPARIAN PLANTS IN MONTANA AND ADJACENT STATESAND  
3.	DELIVER HIGH-QUALITY TRAINING TO AGENCY AND PRIVATE SECTOR PROFESSIONALS TO HELP THEM IDENTIFY, MANAGE AND RESTORE WETLAND BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES.
4.	COLLABORATE WITH OTHER UNIVERSITY AND AGENCY PARTNERS WORKING ON STANDARDIZED WETLAND ASSESSMENT METHODS THAT CAN BE UNIFORMLY APPLIED THROUGHOUT WESTERN STATES AND FED INTO COMMON DATABASES FOR ANALYSIS AND DISSEMINATION.
5.	PROMOTE AND CONDUCT SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH ON WETLAND AND RIPARIAN ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS, INCLUDING RESEARCH ON ASSESSMENT, INVENTORY AND MONITORING APPROACHESAND RESPONSES TO HUMAN AND NATURAL STRESSORSAND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIESAND AND CONSERVATION, PROTECTION AND RESTORATION APPROACHES.

THE TRIBE WILL DEVELOP A REVISED WETLANDS PROGRAM PLAN TO GUIDE WETLAND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES THAT WILL INCREASE WETLAND QUANTITY AND QUALITY ON THE RESERVATION.  AN UPDATED DEFINITION OF &LDQUOANDWATERS OF THE TRIBE&RDQUOAND IS NEEDED TO PROTECT WETLANDS THAT AREN&RSQUOANDT PROTECTED UNDER WOTUS OR CURRENT TRIBAL REGULATIONS. UPDATED MAPS OF SURFACE WATERS ARE NEEDED FOR BETTER DECISION-MAKING, MANAGEMENT AND PLANNING. FURTHERMORE, THE NATIONAL HYDROGRAPHY DATASET FOR MONTANA OFTEN FAILS TO ACCURATELY DISTINGUISH BETWEEN EPHEMERAL, INTERMITTENT AND PERENNIAL STREAMS. UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA WETLAND AND RIPARIAN MAPPING LAB, UTILIZES RIPARIAN MAPPING IMAGERY FROM MULTIPLE YEARS, THUS ALLOWING IDENTIFICATION OF SURFACE WATER CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN WETLANDS. THIS WILL ENABLE THE TRIBE TO IDENTIFY, REGULATE AND MANAGE WETLANDS AND WATERWAYS THAT REQUIRE SPECIFIC TRIBAL DESIGNATION FOR PROTECTION AND REGULATION BECAUSE THEY ARE NO LONGER CONSIDERED &LDQUOANDWATERS OF THE U.S&RDQUOAND. 
PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE AN UPDATED WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN THAT SPECIFICALLY ADDRESSES ALL WETLANDS FOR PROTECTION AND REGULATIONAND A STRONG AND WETLAND-PROTECTIVE DEFINITION OF &LDQUOANDWATERS OF THE TRIBE&RDQUOANDAND UPDATED WETLAND MAPPING THAT INCLUDES EPHEMERAL, INTERMITTENT AND PERENNIAL STREAMSAND TARGETED WETLAND RESTORATION AND PROTECTION SITESAND AND PARTNERSHIPS TO INCREASE WETLAND PROTECTION AND RESTORATION.  PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL LEAD TO INCREASED PROTECTION, REGULATION AND RESTORATION OF TRIBAL WETLANDS AND WILL ULTIMATELY IMPROVE WETLAND AND WATER QUALITY OF THE BLACKFEET RESERVATION. PROJECT GOALS, OBJECTIVES AND ACTIVITIES WILL SUPPORT AND FURTHER DEVELOP THE BLACKFEET TRIBE&RSQUOANDS CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION PLAN.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS FOR THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION (ADEC) TO REFINE ITS WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN (WPP) IN PREPARATION FOR FUTURE CLEAN WATER ACT SECTION 404 STATE ASSUMPTION. ADEC IS REFINING ITS WPP TO INCLUDE 404 ASSUMPTION TO PROVIDE THE STATE WITH GREATER CONTROL OVER THE DEVELOPMENT OF ITS NATURAL RESOURCES WHILE COMPLYING WITH FEDERAL LAW. ASSUMPTION OF THE 404 PROGRAM WOULD REQUIRE SUBSTANTIAL REVISION OF ADEC'S WETLANDS PROGRAM PLAN. AS THE 404 PROGRAM POLICIES AND PROCEDURES ARE DEVELOPED DURING STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT AND COORDINATION WITH THE CORPS AND EPA, THE WETLANDS PROGRAM PLAN WOULD EVOLVE. THE MAIN TASK OF THIS PROJECT IS UPDATING THE WPP TO INCLUDE ASSUMABLE WETLANDS. ADEC WILL WORK WITH A CONTRACTOR TO IDENTIFY ACTIVITIES NECESSARY TO BUILD THE PROGRAM WITH RESPECT TO PROTECTION AND RESTORATION AND WETLAND-SPECIFIC WATER QUALITY STANDARDS. THE PROGRAM MANAGERS FOR THE 404 AND 402 PERMITTING GROUPS WILL COORDINATE AND DRAFT THE REFINED WPP WITH SUBSTANTIAL CONTRACTOR ASSISTANCE. OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE A REFINED WPP WHICH INCLUDES OUTLINED ACTIVITIES UNDER AN ADEC-MANAGED STATE 404 PROGRAM IN FUTURE YEARS. ONCE THE WPP IS REFINED AND REVIEWED, IT WILL BE PUBLISHED ON THE DEPARTMENT'S WEBSITE. NOTICES WILL ALSO BE SENT TO TRIBES DURING THE PUBLIC NOTICE PROCESS FOR REGULATION DEVELOPMENT AND WHEN THE WPP IS AVAILABLE FOR REVIEW AND IS PUBLISHED AS FINAL. ACTIVITIES:ADEC WILL WORK WITH A CONTRACTOR TO IDENTIFY ACTIVITIES IN AN UPDATED WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN (WPP) NECESSARY TO BUILD THE STATE PROGRAM WITH RESPECT TO PROTECTION AND RESTORATION AND WETLAND-SPECIFIC WATER QUALITY STANDARDS. THE PROGRAM MANAGERS FOR THE 404 AND 402 PERMITTING GROUPS WILL COORDINATE AND DRAFT THE REFINED WPP WITH SUBSTANTIAL CONTRACTOR ASSISTANCE.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLE IS AN UPDATED WPP WHICH INCLUDES A STATE 404 PROGRAM. THE OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASED ADEC PREPARATION TO CONSIDER ASSUMPTION OF 404(G) AUTHORITY IN THE FUTURE WITHIN THE STATE. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE CITIZENS OF ALASKA.

BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE OREGON STATE AGENCIES AND OREGON COUNTIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO COMPLETE THE SUPPORT TASKS FOR THE FIRST PHASE OF A PROJECT TO COMPLETE AN ESRI-BASED GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS (GIS) DATASET OF ALL OREGON DEPARTMENT OF STATE LANDS (DSL) REGULATORY PROGRAMS RELATED WETLANDS AND WATERS DELINEATION AND DETERMINATION (WD) STUDY AREA LOCATIONS. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS DSL'S STRATEGIC PLAN GOALS BY INCREASING PROGRAM EFFICIENCY AND THE ACCESSIBILITY TO DSL WD FILES FOR STAFF, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, OTHER GROUPS, AND THE PUBLIC BY CONTINUING TO ENHANCE THE STATEWIDE WETLANDS INVENTORY (SWI).
