DESCRIPTION:
THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS FOR ECOLOGY TO DEVELOP MONITORING GUIDANCE FOR WETLAND COMPENSATORY MITIGATION SITES IN THE STATE OF WASHINGTON. THIS AWARD WILL ALLOW WASHINGTON STATE TO BE BETTER POSITIONED TO ANSWER THE MAIN QUESTION ADDRESSED IN EPA FRAMEWORK (COMPENSATORY MITIGATION SITE PERFORMANCE), 'HOW WELL DO COMPENSATION SITES MEET THEIR STATED GOALS AND PERMIT REQUIREMENTS?' TO IMPROVE OUR ABILITY TO EVALUATE REGULATORY COMPLIANCE AND ECOLOGICAL SUCCESS OF COMPENSATORY MITIGATION PROJECTS IS CRITICAL.  
ACTIVITIES:
PROJECT TASKS INCLUDE: IDENTIFYING THE RANGE OF CURRENT MONITORING PROTOCOLS USED IN TYPICAL PROJECTS IN WA AND OTHER STATES; DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENTS A COMMUNICATIONS AND OUTREACH PLAN; ESTABLISH AN ADVISORY TEAM TO REVIEW CURRENT PROTOCOLS; PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE A MONITORING GUIDANCE DOCUMENT; AND DEVELOP TRAINING MATERIALS FOR STAFF WHO REVIEW MONITORING PLANS. 
OUTCOMES:
THIS PROJECT'S OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE GUIDANCE FOR ENSURING THAT FOR COMPENSATORY MITIGATION PROJECT SITE MONITORING PLANS INCLUDE ADEQUATE AND ACCURATE DATA COLLECTION METHODS; THAT MONITORING DATA THAT IS COLLECTED CAN DEMONSTRATE THAT PROJECT GOALS, OBJECTIVE AND PERFORMANCE STANDARDS ARE MET; AND THAT COMPENSATORY MITIGATION SITE DATA THAT IS COLLECTED CAN BE USED TO COMPARE ACROSS PROJECT SITES TO DRAW CONCLUSIONS ABOUT WHETHER AND HOW COMPENSATORY  MITIGATION IS CONTRIBUTING TO ACHIEVING THE STATE'S NO NET LOSS OF WETLAND FUNCTIONS AND AREA GOAL. BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE TRIBAL, STATE AND THE FEDERAL AGENCIES.

SUBRECIPIENT:
NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.

DESCRIPTION:
THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION ON HOW WETLANDS IN WASHINGTON STATE ARE RESPONDING TO CLIMATE CHANGE IN ORDER TO INFORM ACTIONS THAT CAN BE TAKEN TO INCREASE RESILIENCY OF THESE CRITICAL ECOSYSTEMS. WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES PROPOSES BUILDING UPON EXISTING EFFORTS FOCUSED ON ASSESSING CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY BY DEVELOPING A METRIC-BASED PROTOCOL FOR SYSTEMATICALLY ASSESSING THE VULNERABILITY OF FINE-SCALE WETLAND ECOSYSTEM TYPES IN THE STATE OF WASHINGTON. 
ACTIVITIES:
THE PROJECT WILL START WITH ELEMENTS USED IN NATURESERVE'S HABITAT CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY INDEX (COMER ET AL. 2019; HCCVI) AND SPECIES-FOCUSED CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY INDEX (YOUNG ET AL. 2016; 4 CCVI), TO DEVELOP A PROTOCOL TAILORED TO ASSESSING THE VULNERABILITY OF BIOTIC AND ABIOTIC COMPONENTS OF WASHINGTON'S DIFFERENT WETLAND TYPES. WDNR WILL DEVELOP AN ASSESSMENT PROTOCOL, PREPARE DATASETS, ASSESS CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY OF TARGET WETLANDS, AND DISSEMINATE DATA.
OUTCOMES:
PROJECT RESULTS WILL INCLUDE A LIST OF WETLAND TYPES AT GREATEST RISK OF EXPERIENCING CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS. DESCRIPTION:TO PROVE THE VALIDITY OF OKLAHOMA RAPID ASSESSMENT METHOD (OKRAM) AS A RAPID MEASURE OF WETLAND CONDITION, SEVERAL OBSTACLES TO FINAL VALIDATION HAVE PERSISTED.  OBSTACLES INCLUDE (1) SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL VARIABILITY OF THE BIOTIC MEASURES USED AS THE PRIMARY MEANS OF OKRAM VALIDATION AND (2) SUFFICIENT STUDY SITES TO SPLIT THE DATASET INTO MODEL REFINEMENT (CALIBRATION) COMPONENT AND AN ASSESSMENT OF MODEL FUNCTIONALITY (VALIDATION) COMPONENT. THIS PROJECT WILL SERVE TO ADDRESS AND RESOLVE THOSE OBSTACLES BY (1) COMPILING THE OVER 250 OKRAM ASSESSMENTS COMPLETED INTO A COMPREHENSIVE DATABASE, (2) IDENTIFYING SPATIAL AND WETLAND CLASS DATA GAPS AND COMPLETING ADDITIONAL ASSESSMENTS, AND (3) REFINING RIVERINE AND DIGRESSIONAL OKRAM MODULES THROUGH DATA ANALYSES OF THE COMPLETE OKRAM DATASET.  FURTHERMORE, SHARING OF THE COMPREHENSIVE DATASET THROUGH THE OKLAHOMA WETLANDS WEBSITE AND COORDINATION WITH THE US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS (USACE) WILL HELP TO IMPROVE TRANSPARENCY IN OKRAM DEVELOPMENT AND WORK TOWARDS INTEGRATION OF THE METHOD INTO CLEAR WATER ACT (CWA) PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO (1) REFINE DEPRESSIONAL AND RIVERINE OKRAM MODULES, (2) CONTINUE TO DEVELOP THE LACUSTRINE OKRAM MODULE, AND (3) IMPROVE UTILITY AND APPLICABILITY OF OKRAM IN WETLAND MANAGEMENT IN OKLAHOMA. THESE GOALS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY COMBINING THE OKRAM DATASETS COLLECTED THROUGH PREVIOUS WETLAND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS AND FURTHER BOLSTERING OUR ANALYSES BY INCLUDING APPROXIMATELY 100 OKRAM ASSESSMENTS COMPLETED DURING THE 2016 AND 2021 NATIONAL WETLAND CONDITION ASSESSMENT (NWCA), WHICH WILL PROVIDE A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO IMPROVE UPON EXISTING OKRAM METHODS THROUGH MODEL VALIDATION. SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES INCLUDE SYNTHESIZE PREVIOUS OKRAM DATA COLLECTION EFFORTS TO REFINE AND IMPROVE OUR BROADSCALE APPLICATION OF OKRAM FOR WETLANDS THROUGHOUT THE STATE, DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE DATASET FROM GT;300 OKRAM ASSESSMENTS THAT WILL ALLOW FOR GREATER STATISTICAL POWER TO COMPLETE CALIBRATION AND VALIDATION AT RIVERINE AND DEPRESSIONAL WETLANDS AS WELL AS ALLOW US TO ACCOUNT FOR REGIONAL VARIATIONS IN FLORISTIC QUALITY INDEX (FQI) REFERENCE CONDITIONS, AND CREATE AN OKRAM WEB PORTAL WITH A USER-FRIENDLY INTERFACE TO VISUALIZE AND DOWNLOAD OKRAM DATA.  SUBRECIPIENT:1. DEVELOPMENT OF A QUALITY ASSURANCE PROJECT PLAN.
2. COMPILATION OF EXISTING OKRAM DATA INTO A STATEWIDE COMPREHENSIVE DATASET
3.  INTEGRATE OKRAM INTO CWA PROGRAMS
4.  COMPLETE ADDITIONAL OKRAM ASSESSMENTS TO FILL DATA GAPS
5.  DATA ANALYSIS AND STATEWIDE VALIDATION
6.  DEVELOPMENT OF OKRAM WEB PORTAL
7.  DEVELOPMENT OF A COMPREHENSIVE FINAL REPORT THAT NOT ONLY SUMMARIZES THE METHODS AND RESULTS OF THE PROJECT BUT INCLUDES A REVIEW OF ANALYSES AND PREVIOUS STATES OF DEVELOPMENT FOR OKRAM.  THE FINAL REPORT WILL INCLUDE PROGRESS TOWARDS IMPLEMENTATION OF OKRAM IN WETLAND MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS INCLUDING CWA MITIGATION FOR THE STATE OF OKLAHOMAOUTCOMES:1. DESCRIPTION:THE NEW MEXICO ENVIRONMENT DEPARTMENT (NMED) SURFACE WATER QUALITY BUREAU (SWQB) WETLANDS PROGRAM PROPOSES TO MAP AND CLASSIFY WETLANDS IN THE NORTHERN PORTION OF NEW MEXICO ALONG NATIVE NATION AND TRIBAL BOUNDARIES, AS PART OF OUR EFFORTS TO UPDATE MAPPING OF ALL NEW MEXICO'S WETLANDS. PROJECT TASKS INCLUDE 1) ADMINISTERING A CONTRACT WITH A MAPPING CONTRACTOR, 2) CONDUCTING A LITERATURE SEARCH, ASSEMBLING A TECHNICAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE (TAC) AND ASSIGN TASKS, 3) UPDATING A QAPP, 4) LEADING TAC MEETINGS, 5) ASSEMBLING IMAGERY AND A GEODATABASE, CONDUCTING PRE- AND POST-MAPPING FIELD REVIEWS AND WETLAND MAPPING WITH COWARDIN, WESTERN RIPARIAN, LANDSCAPE POSITION, LANDFORM, WATER FLOW PATH AND WATERBODY TYPE (LLWW) AND HYDROGEOMORPHIC (HGM) CLASSIFICATIONS; ASSIGNING WETLAND FUNCTIONS TO DIFFERENT WETLAND TYPES, MODELING WETLANDS CLASSIFIED SEGMENTS FOR WATER QUALITY STANDARDS, AND QUALITY ASSURANCE, 6) TRANSFERRING PROJECT RESULTS TO INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS AND UPDATING ONLINE AGENCY MAPPING PRODUCTS, 7) ATTENDING CONFERENCES, TRAININGS OR WORKSHOPS APPLICABLE TO PROJECT AND PRESENTING WHENEVER POSSIBLE. THE TAC WILL BE ESTABLISHED TO PROVIDE INPUT AND EXPERTISE. TRANSFER OF MAPPING PRODUCTS AND TECHNOLOGY WILL INCLUDE PRESENTATIONS TO WATERSHED GROUPS, AGENCIES, TRIBES AND CONSORTIUMS, THE UPDATED STORY MAP, COPIES OF THE FINAL REPORT AND INTERACTIVE MAPS POSTED ON THE SWQB WETLANDS WEBSITE. THIS PROJECT WILL DESIGNATE CLASSIFIED WETLAND SEGMENTS AND IDENTIFY WETLAND FUNCTIONS (PROPOSED DESIGNATED USES) FOR DEVELOPING WETLAND WATER QUALITY STANDARDS. PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE REVISED WETLANDS MAPPING AND CLASSIFICATION COVERING ~ 35,000 SQUARE MILES FOR THE PROJECT AREA THAT CURRENTLY HAS INCOMPLETE DATA. FUNCTIONAL CORRELATION, HGM SUBCLASS ASSIGNMENTS, CLASSIFIED SEGMENTS, PRESENTATIONS, AND INTERACTIVE MAPPING RESOURCES ARE ADDITIONAL PRODUCTS.ACTIVITIES:*ASSESS AND MONITOR WETLAND RESOURCES BY THE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF LANDSCAPE, RAPID ASSESSMENT, AND INTENSIVE MONITORING TOOLS (WPP P.13). THE COMPREHENSIVE LANDSCAPE LEVEL INVENTORY AND CLASSIFICATION THAT THE SWQB WETLANDS PROGRAM HAS SUCCESSFULLY USED TO MAP WETLANDS IN NEW MEXICO WILL BE APPLIED AND FURTHER DEVELOPED TO A NEW AREA.
- EXPAND AND IMPROVE WETLANDS ACTION PLAN (WAP) PROGRAM (WPP P.16). THE PROJECT PROVIDES MAPPING AND CLASSIFICATION PRODUCTS FOR EXISTING AND FUTURE WAPS AND PROVIDES MAPPING AND CLASSIFICATION TRAINING TO PARTNERS CREATING WAPS.
- CREATE STRATEGIES THAT BUILD CAPACITY ON PUBLIC LANDS IN NEW MEXICO (WPP P.18). THIS PROJECT BUILDS CAPACITY BY PROVIDING A TOOL TO HELP MANAGE PUBLIC LANDS. A COMPREHENSIVE WETLANDS INVENTORY WILL PROMOTE MORE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT FOR WETLANDS PROTECTION AND RESTORATION.
- CREATE STRATEGIES THAT BUILD CAPACITY AT THE LOCAL LEVEL (WPP P.19). THIS PROJECT BUILDS CAPACITY AT THE LOCAL LEVEL BY DISSEMINATING INFORMATION TO ORGANIZATIONS AND COMMUNITIES ABOUT LOCAL WETLAND RESOURCES.
- DEVELOP WATER QUALITY STANDARDS FOR WETLANDS (WPP P. 20). THIS PROJECT WILL ASSIGN ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONS (PROPOSED DESIGNATED USES) TO WETLAND TYPES AND CLASSIFY WETLAND SEGMENTS AS IMPORTANT NEXT STEPS FOR NARRATIVE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS FOR WETLANDS, AS WELL AS IDENTIFY POTENTIAL CANDIDATE WETLANDS TO PROPOSE FOR SPECIAL PROTECTION SUCH AS ONRW DESIGNATION.
SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE PROJECT OUTPUTS INCLUDE NWI, LLWW, HGM AND RIPARIAN WETLANDS MAPPING AND CLASSIFICATIONS COMPLETED FOR APPROXIMATELY 119 USGS QUADRANGLES, WITH THE REVIEW AND UPDATE OF 366 USGS QUADRANGLES TO COMPLY WITH NEW NWI GUIDANCE (NWI VERSION 2.0) FOR LINEAR FEATURES THAT WITH INSURE THAT ALL OF THE NEW MEXICO NWI DATA IS CONSISTENT STATEWIDE. THIS UPDATE WILL ALSO PRODUCE FUNCTIONAL ANALYSIS AND CLASSIFIED SEGMENTS FOR THESE AREAS. THE NWI GEODATABASES WILL BE UPLOADED ON THE USFWS NWI V.2 FOR NATIONAL USE AND THE ADDITIONAL CLASSIFICATIONS, FUNCTIONAL ANALYSIS AND CLA

DESCRIPTION:WITH THIS AWARD NEW MEXICO WILL DEVELOP AND DEMONSTRATE NEW METHODS FOR RESTORING FEN WETLANDS AND TO RESTORE AT LEAST 70 ACRES OF WETLANDS ON THE CARSON AND CIBOLA NATIONAL FORESTS (NF) IN NEW MEXICO. THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP INNOVATIVE METHODS THAT RESTORE HYDROLOGY AND RE-WET FORMER FEN WETLANDS WHERE TRAMPLING, TRAILING AND EROSION GULLIES REMOVED SOILS AND WETLAND VEGETATION, AND REDUCED THE WATER-HOLDING CAPACITY OF THE FEN. THE FENS THAT WILL BE RESTORED ARE CRITICAL AS THE HEADWATER SOURCES OF PERENNIAL STREAMS. WETLAND DIMENSIONS, WATER SOURCE, HYDROLOGICAL PROCESSES, VEGETATION AND DEPOSITIONAL HISTORY OF DEGRADED FEN WETLANDS WILL BE COMPARED TO REFERENCE CONDITIONS. TREATMENT WITH ON-SITE AND NATURAL MATERIALS FOR THE FEN AND CONTRIBUTING WATERSHED WILL BE DEMONSTRATED.ACTIVITIES:TASKS WILL INCLUDE: 1) ADMINISTERING AND REPORTING; 2)CONDUCTING FIELD RECONNAISSANCE AND COLLECTING DATA ON GEOLOGY, SOILS, HYDROLOGY, VEGETATION AND SEDIMENT DEPOSITION TO SUPPORT RESTORATION METHODS, TIMING AND INSTALLATION; 3) DEVELOPING A QAPP, PRE-AND POST-MONITORING; 4) ORGANIZING WAP STEERING COMMITTEES AND WRITING TWO WAPS; 5) DESIGNING RESTORATION FOR EACH SITE; 6) OBTAINING FEDERAL/STATE CLEARANCES AND CONSTRUCTING THE RESTORATION: 7) CONDUCTING FOUR VOLUNTEER RESTORATION WORKSHOPS AND FOUR FIELDTRIPS TO SHOWCASE THE PROJECT; 8) CREATING AND DISSEMINATING A TECHNICAL GUIDE AND OUTREACH; 9)CONFERENCES/TRAINING.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE: 1)70+ ACRES RESTORED WETLANDS; 2) NEW TECHNIQUES DEMONSTRATED; 3) TWO WAPS; 4) MONITORING RESULTS; 5)TECHNICAL GUIDE AND OUTREACH; AND 6)TRAINED VOLUNTEERS AND STAFF. TWO WETLANDS ACTION PLANS (WAPS) FOR WATERSHEDS IN THE CIBOLA AND CARSON NFS WHERE FEN WETLANDS EXIST WILL BE DEVELOPED TO GUIDE FUTURE RESTORATION, PROTECTION, MANAGEMENT, MONITORING AND OUTREACH IN A COORDINATED AND COMPREHENSIVE MANNER. RESTORATION DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION TECHNIQUES WILL BE SHARED WITH AGENCIES, LANDOWNERS, RESTORATION VOLUNTEERS, AND THE PUBLIC THROUGH FOUR RESTORATION WORKSHOPS, FOUR GUIDED TOURS, PRESENTATIONS AT NM WETLANDS ROUNDTABLES, AND THE DISSEMINATION OF A TECHNICAL GUIDE. THE NEW TECHNIQUES WILL FOCUS ON DEGRADED FENS WHERE SOURCES OF SOIL SATURATION HAVE BEEN DIVERTED OR DIMINISHED THROUGH DEGRADATION OF THE CONTRIBUTING WATERSHED

DESCRIPTION:THE CITY OF BENTONVILLE, AR IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE WATERSHED CONSERVATION RESOURCE CENTER (WCRC) PROPOSES TO CONDUCT AN INVENTORY AND ASSESS THE CONDITION OF RIPARIAN, WETLAND AREAS, OTHER NATURAL FEATURES AND STREAMBANKS FOR 5 MILES OF URBAN STREAMS IN THE OZARK HIGHLANDS ECOREGION. INITIAL STREAMBANK CONDITION MONITORING WILL BE CONDUCTED.

INITIAL STREAMBANK CONDITION MONITORING WILL BE CONDUCTED.

SELECTION AND ESTABLISHMENT OF NATIVE PLANTS AND REMOVAL OF INVASIVE PLANTS IN RIPARIAN AND WETLAND AREAS TO PROTECT WATER QUALITY AND CREATE WILDLIFE HABITAT.OUTCOMES:THE EXPECTED ENVIRONMENTAL OUTCOMES FROM THIS PROJECT ARE: 1) IMPROVE THE DECISION MAKING ABILITY OF THE CITY AND WATERSHED PLANNER IN CONDUCTING RESTORATION OF STREAMS, WETLANDS AND RIPARIAN AREAS; PRESERVATION OF HEALTHY STREAMS, WETLANDS AND OTHER NATURAL FEATURES; AND REDUCTION OF SEDIMENT AND NUTRIENTS FROM STREAMBANK EROSION TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY WITHIN THE WATERSHED.  2) IMPROVE CITY'S STAFF ABILITY TO EVALUATE PROPOSED DEVELOPMENT, ZONING AND OTHER ACTIVITIES THAT CAN IMPACT STREAMS AND WETLANDS. 3) REDUCE INVASIVE SPECIES OF PLANTS IN THE TREATED RIPARIAN AREAS. 4) INCREASE PERCENTAGE OF NATIVE PLANTS ALONG THE RIPARIAN. 5) INCREASE QUALITY OF WETLANDS, RIPARIAN, AND OTHER NATURAL FEATURES

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO REFINE THE RESTORABLE WETLAND IDENTIFICATION PROTOCOL (RWIP) AND APPLY THE UPDATED METHOD ACROSS OKLAHOMA. RWIP WAS DEVELOPED BY OKLAHOMA CONSERVATION COMMISSION (OCC) IN 2015 AS A DESKTOP TOOL TO IDENTIFY LOCATIONS THAT WOULD MOST LIKELY SUPPORT WETLAND RESTORATION, AND FURTHER RANK THOSE SITES BASED ON POTENTIAL TO IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF DOWNSTREAM RECEIVING WATERBODIES (OCC 2016). IN 2018, RWIP WAS APPLIED SUCCESSFULLY ACROSS THE STATE AND FIELD VERIFICATION CONFIRMED THAT THE PROTOCOL CAN BE USED AS AN EFFECTIVE SCREENING TOOL FOR LOCATING HISTORIC WETLANDS AND MARGINALLY WET AREAS (88% OF FIELD VERIFIED SITES). HOWEVER, THE ORIGINAL PROTOCOL PROVIDED LESS INFORMATION ON THE FEASIBILITY OF RESTORING HYDROLOGY SUFFICIENT TO CREATE FUNCTIONAL WETLANDS AT IDENTIFIED LOCATIONS (57% OF MARGINALLY WET AREAS; OCC IN PROGRESS). THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD TO MISSISSIPPI DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY IN THE AMOUNT OF $163,980. THE PURPOSE OF THE AWARD IS TO FUND THE RECIPIENT'S EFFORTS TO SUPPORT WETLANDS PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT IN THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE INCREASING THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF WETLANDS IN THE UNITED STATES BY CONSERVING AND RESTORING WETLAND ACREAGE AND IMPROVING WETLAND CONDITIONS. OUTCOMES, OUTPUTS, AND DELIVERABLES INCLUDE BETTER TRACKING AND REAL TIME DATA FOR 401 WATER QUALITY CERTIFICATION REGULATORY PROGRAM; DEVELOPMENT OF TOOLS AND GUIDANCE FOR THE REGULATED PUBLIC WITH AN EASE OF ACCESS; STAKEHOLDER TRAINING AND OUTREACH WILL DOCUMENT THE CHANGES MADE TO STREAMLINE THE 401 WATER QUALITY CERTIFICATION REVIEW PROCESS; AND PROJECT PROGRESS REPORTS. THE CITIZENS IN THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI ARE THE DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT. THERE ARE NO SUBAWARDS.

THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $35,220 TO THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI TO FUND THE RECIPIENT'S EFFORTS TO SUPPORT WETLANDS PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT. THE PURPOSE OF THE PROGRAM IS TO INCREASE THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF WETLANDS IN THE U.S. BY CONSERVING AND RESTORING WETLAND ACREAGE AND IMPROVING WETLAND CONDITIONS. OUTCOMES, OUTPUTS, AND DELIVERABLES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN IDENTIFICATION PROCESS OF WATERS OF THE STATE TO FOSTER A MORE CONSISTENT AND RELIABLE DECISION MATRIX, SUPPORTIVE OF EPA CORE ELEMENTS OF MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT, VOLUNTARY RESTORATION/PROTECTION, AND REGULATORY FRAMEWORK. DEVELOPMENT OF TOOLS FOR USE BY STAFF AND STAKEHOLDERS RESULTING IN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONS OF WATERS IN THE STATE TO BETTER ADDRESS AVOIDANCE AND MINIMIZATION OF IMPACTS AS WELL AS IDENTIFY SPECIFIC MITIGATION GOALS. THESE TOOLS WILL HELP IDENTIFY CUMULATIVE IMPACTS ON THE WATERSHED AND PROVIDE BETTER FEEDBACK TO APPLICANTS TO ADDRESS IN THEIR APPLICATIONS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $199,164 TO NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY TO CREATE AN ONLINE INTERACTIVE GUIDE TO WETLANDS PLANTS, DEVELOP WETLANDS DIGITAL APPLICATION AND PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION.ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE CREATION OF ONLINE, INTERACTIVE GUIDE TO NORTH CAROLINA (NC) WETLAND PLANTS, INVESTIGATE OPTIONS AND EXAMPLES FOR DESIGN OF ONLINE INTERACTIVE GUIDE, OVERSEE DESIGN AND CREATION OF ONLINE GUIDE, COMPILE INFORMATION AND PHOTOS FOR EXTRA, TEST AND REVISE ONLINE GUIDE; OVERSEE DESIGN AND CREATION OF ONLINE GUIDE; COMPILE INFORMATION AND PHOTOS FOR EXTRA SPECIES; TEST AND REVISE ON-LINE GUIDE. THIS PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES THE DEVELOPMENT OF NC WETLANDS DIGITAL APPLICATION, SUBCONTRACT WITH SOFTWARE DEVELOPER AND OVERSEE WORK OF SOFTWARE DEVELOPER IN CREATING, TESTING, AND RELEASING APP; CONTRACT AND COORDINATE WITH COLORADO NHP FOR MODIFICATION OF A COPY OF THEIR DATABASE FOR INPUT INTO THE APP; COMPILE CONTENT AND CREATE WETLAND PLANT DATABASE FOR INPUT INTO APP; TEST AND REVISE APP; AND EXPLORE MONETIZATION OF APP. EDUCATION AND OUTREACH - AN IMPORTANT PIECE OF THIS PROJECT IS ENSURING PUBLICITY AROUND THE RELEASE OF THE NEW FREE ELECTRONIC GUIDES, AS WELL AS EDUCATION ON HOW TO USE THEM.SUBRECIPIENT:SUB AWARDS INCLUDE NC STATE WEB DEVELOPERS AND COLORADO STATE DATA BASE CONSULTANT TO DEVELOP DIGITAL APP.  STATE TEMPORARY PERSONAL THROUGH TEMPORARY SOLUTIONS .OUTCOMES:OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED ACCESS TO WETLAND PLANT IDENTIFICATION AND GENERAL WETLAND INFORMATION FOR NC, IMPROVED IDENTIFICATION OF COMMON WETLAND PLANTS IN NC, IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF WETLAND CONDITION USING UPDATED INDICATOR STATUSES AND C VALUES, BROADENED UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF WETLAND RESOURCES, INCREASED INTEREST IN WETLAND RESOURCES IN NC, IMPROVED MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT OF BASELINE CONDITION IN NC'S WETLAND RESOURCES, IMPROVED WETLAND PROTECTION EFFORTS THROUGH IDENTIFICATION OF WETLAND PLANTS AND WETLAND RESOURCES, INCREASED STAKEHOLDER AND DECISIONMAKER'S UNDERSTANDING AND KNOWLEDGE THROUGH TRAINING AND OUTREACH FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS, STATE WETLAND STAFF, THE PUBLIC, AND/OR OTHER PARTNERS. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE INTERNAL MONTHLY MEETINGS, BI-MONTHLY MEETINGS W/SUB AWARDEE'S AND SEMI ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORTS. THE DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT ARE THE CITIZENS OF NC.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $308,657 TO SUPPORT NORTH CAROLINA'S ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY'S WETLAND PROGRAMS DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE STORM RESPONSE FLOOD STORAGE CAPACITY IN URBAN PIEDMONT WETLANDS IN RALEIGH, NORTH CAROLINA USING VARIOUS METHODS.ACTIVITIES:PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PARTICIPATE IN WATERSHED PLANNING GROUPS AND LOCAL PARTNERSHIPS, DEVELOP QUALITY ASSURANCE PROJECT PLAN (QAPP), BACKGROUND RESEARCH, SITE SELECTION AND RECONNAISSANCE, DATA COLLECTION, OBTAINING EXTERNAL DATA, AND DATABASE COMPILATION, DATA ANALYSIS AND REPORT ON FINDINGS, AND STORY MAP AND DISSEMINATION OF RESULTS.SUBRECIPIENT:THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE A SUB AWARD TO NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF ADMINISTRATION FOR TEMP EMPLOYEES TO WORK ON THIS PROJECT.OUTCOMES:THE DELIVERABLES INCLUDE; SEMI ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, PRESENTATIONS, QUALITY ASSURANCE PROJECT PLAN AND DIGITAL MAPPING. THE OUTCOMES AND OUTPUTS FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE: STUDY PLAN FOR EVALUATING THE ECOLOGICAL PERFORMANCE OF NATURAL URBAN WETLANDS AND INCORPORATING THE RESULTS/FINDINGS/LESSONS LEARNED INTO FUTURE COMPENSATORY MITIGATION PROJECT DECISION-MAKING TO HELP DETERMINE MITIGATION PROGRAM SUCCESS; DATABASE TO HELP LOCAL DECISION-MAKERS INTEGRATE FLOOD IMPACTS AND CLIMATE RESILIENCY INTO WETLAND PROTECTION AND RESTORATION; TOOLS TO HELP STATE/LOCAL GOVERNMENT DECISION-MAKERS INTEGRATE WETLAND PROTECTION AND RESTORATION INTO INTEGRATED WATERSHED PLANNING ESPECIALLY WITH REGARDS TO HAZARD MITIGATION/FLOOD/DROUGHT PLANNING AND CLIMATE RESILIENCY; PROTOCOLS AND ASSESSMENT CRITERIA (FLOOD STORAGE) THAT CAN BE USED TO IDENTIFY WETLAND RESTORATION AND PROTECTION PRIORITIES ESPECIALLY WITH REGARD TO ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE OR CLIMATE RESILIENCY; STRATEGIES THAT CONSIDER HAZARD MITIGATION/FLOOD/DROUGHT PLANNING, CLIMATE RESILIENCY, AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE IN WETLAND RESTORATION AND PROTECTION; EDUCATION AND OUTREACH MATERIALS FOR WETLAND STAFF, STORM WATER MANAGERS AND MODELERS, CITY PLANNERS, THE PUBLIC, AND OTHER SECTORS; STORY MAP PRESENTING THE WALNUT CREEK WETLAND FLOODING INFORMATION IN NON-TECHNICAL TERMS FOR COMMUNICATION WITH RESIDENTS IN THE LOCAL COMMUNITIES; FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT AND PUBLIC STORY MAP SUMMARIZING STUDY RESULTS. THE OUTCOMES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE: INCREASED QUANTITY OF WETLANDS; IMPROVED WETLAND PROTECTION EFFORTS, THROUGH BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF FLOOD STORAGE BENEFIT/FUNCTION AND PRIORITIZATION OF WETLANDS FOR PROTECTION; INCREASED STAKEHOLDER AND DECISIONMAKER'S UNDERSTANDING OF WETLAND FUNCTION IN TERMS OF FLOOD ATTENUATION; IMPROVED WETLAND BASELINE CONDITION ASSESSMENTS TO ADDRESS HAZARD MITIGATION/FLOOD/DROUGHT EFFECTS AND CLIMATE ADAPTATION; IMPROVED DATA TO USE IN MODELING POTENTIAL HYDROLOGIC CHANGE, WETLAND LOSSES, OR WETLAND INCREASES ON A LANDSCAPE FOR USE IN INFORMING STAKEHOLDERS AND DECISIONMAKERS; INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF WETLAND FUNCTION FOR WATERSHED PLANNING STAFF AND STORM WATER MANAGEMENT STAFF; INCREASED STAKEHOLDER AND DECISIONMAKER'S KNOWLEDGE THROUGH TRAINING AND OUTREACH STATE/TERRITORIAL/TRIBAL WETLAND STAFF, THE PUBLIC, AT RISK COMMUNITIES, AND/OR OTHER PARTNERS; AND IMPROVED BASELINE INFORMATION ON WETLAND AND PERFORMANCE TO INFORM STATE REGULATORY PROGRAMS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE CITIZENS OF THE STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS FOR THE CHUGACH REGIONAL RESOURCES COMMISSION (CRRC) TO COMPLETE NATIONAL WETLANDS INVENTORY MAPPING FOR ONE OF THE HYDROLOGIC UNITS IDENTIFIED AS A SUB WATERSHED (HUC10) WITHIN THE TRADITIONAL LANDS IN WESTERN PRINCE WILLIAM SOUND OF THE CHUGACH REGION IN SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA THAT ARE THE TRADITIONAL TERRITORY OF THE ALUTIIQ ALASKA NATIVE PEOPLE. THE NATIONAL WETLAND INVENTORY (NWI) DATABASE FOR ALASKA IS OUTDATED FOR THE CHENEGA IRA COUNCIL&RSQUOANDS (CIRAC) TRADITIONAL LANDS AND NEEDS TO BE UPDATED TO ALLOW FOR MEANINGFUL MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF AQUATIC RESOURCES. THE MAIN TASK OF THIS PROJECT IS THE CREATION OF AN UPDATED GIS MAP OF THE AREAS OF INTEREST THAT WOULD MEET THE NATIONAL WETLAND INVENTORY STANDARD (FGDC 2013).THIS PROJECT WILL CULMINATE IN A GEODATABASE AT A 0.5-ACRE TARGET MAPPING UNIT FOR EACH HUC10 THAT WILL HELP THE ORGANIZATION AND ITS TRIBAL MEMBERS TO BE STRATEGIC IN PLANNING FUTURE MONITORING AND DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS. PROJECT TASKS INCLUDES: SETTING UP A GEODATABASE OF EXISTING GEOSPATIAL LAYERSAND GIS MODEL DEVELOPMENT FOR SEGMENTATION EFFORT INCLUDING: WETLAND MAPPING THROUGH IMAGE SEGMENTATION, TABULATING EXISTING PLOT DATA, AND PLANNING AND CONDUCTING FIELD WORK FOR FIELD VERIFICATIONAND REVIEWING INTERIM MAP PRODUCTSAND APPLYING LANDSCAPE POSITION, LANDFORM, WATER FLOW PATH, AND TYPE OF WATERBODY DESCRIPTORS TO EACH WETLAND OR WATERBODYAND AND GETTING THE GEODATABASE READY FOR UPLOADING TO NWI MAPPER. DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE: A GEODATABASE WILL BE SUPPLIED TO THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) FOR UPLOADING TO THE NATIONAL WETLANDS MAPPER, A PUBLICLY AVAILABLE, ONLINE PLATFORM, ALLOWING USERS TO EASILY VIEW WETLAND EXTENT AND DOWNLOAD GEOSPATIAL DATA. SUBRECIPIENTS OF THIS AWARD ARE: UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA ANCHORAGE- THE ALASKA CENTER FOR CONSERVATION SCIENCE (ACCS) WHO WILL ASSIST WITH UPDATING THE EXISTING NWI DATA LAYER AND PROVIDE GEO REFERENCE INFORMATION ALLOWING THE NWI LAYER TO BE AUGMENTED WITH ADDITIONAL NWI MODIFIERS. BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE TRIBAL, STATE AND FEDERAL INTERESTS WITHIN THE CHUGACH REGION.

MICHIGAN'S WETLANDS PROGRAM HAS IDENTIFIED THE NEED TO IMPROVE PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF WETLAND AND STREAM CONNECTIVITY, AS WELL AS ADVANCE RESTORATION OF RIPARIAN/FLOODPLAIN WETLANDS. THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON ADDRESSING THIS NEED THROUGH CREATING A NEW POSITION IN THE WATER RESOURCES DIVISION (WRD) TO DEVELOP AND PROMOTE PROGRAMS RELATING TO DAM REMOVALS, STREAM RESTORATION, AND HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS THAT INVOLVE FLOODPLAIN AND RIPARIAN WETLAND RESTORATION. THIS POSITION WILL ALSO FOCUS ON DEVELOPMENT OF TRAINING FOR STAFF AND EXTERNAL USERS ON DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS AND BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR STREAM RESTORATION PROJECTS, AND DEVELOPMENT OF OTHER OUTREACH MATERIALS. FINAL PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE AN IMPROVED PROCESS FOR EVALUATION OF DAM REMOVALS, STREAM RESTORATION, AND FLOODPLAIN AND WETLAND RESTORATION PROJECTS, TRAINING AND TRAINING MATERIALS FOR WRD STAFF, WEBINARS FOR ENVIRONMENTAL PROFESSIONALS, UPDATED WEB CONTENT, AND NEW EDUCATION AND OUTREACH MATERIALS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT IS TO ENHANCE WETLAND AWARENESS, TRAINING, MAPPING, CONSERVATION, RESTORATION, MONITORING, REGULATION, AND COORDINATION STRATEGIES.  THIS PROJECT WILL REFINE INDIANA'S WETLANDS PROGRAM BY DEVELOPING A CENTRALIZED PERMITTING, COMPLIANCE, AND MITIGATION E-PORTAL AND TRACKING SYSTEM. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO INCLUDE FUNDING FOR EQUIPPING INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT (IDEM) STAFF AND PARTNERING AGENCIES WITH THE TRAINING AND EQUIPMENT NEEDED TO ADMINISTER THEIR DAY-TO-DAY RESPONSIBILITIES TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE WATER RESOURCES ACROSS THE STATE.

TO IMPROVE WETLAND PROTECTION, MONITORING, AND ASSESSMENT EFFORTS, THE STOCKBRIDGE-MUNSEE COMMUNITY (SMC, 'TRIBE') PROPOSES AN UPDATE OF THE WETLAND INVENTORY WITHIN THE HISTORIC SMC RESERVATION BOUNDARIES. WETLANDS WILL BE MAPPED AND CLASSIFIED USING UPDATED, HIGH-RESOLUTION GIS DATASETS. MAPPING EFFORTS WILL INCLUDE IDENTIFICATION OF POTENTIAL EPHEMERAL PONDS. POTENTIAL PONDS WILL BE FIELD-VERIFIED, AND A SUBSET WILL BE MONITORED TO COLLECT BASELINE DATA REGARDING HYDROLOGY, SURROUNDING VEGETATION, AND AMPHIBIANS. LONG-TERM MONITORING PROTOCOLS WILL BE ESTABLISHED TO ASSESS THE IMPACT OF SURROUNDING TIMBER HARVEST ACTIVITIES ON THESE ECOSYSTEMS. FINAL PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE AN UPDATED WETLAND INVENTORY FOR THE ENTIRE HISTORIC SMC RESERVATION, INCLUDING EPHEMERAL PONDS, ESTABLISHED LONG-TERM EPHEMERAL POND MONITORING SITES AND MONITORING PROTOCOLS, AND BASELINE DATA DESCRIBING THE CONDITION OF THE EPHEMERAL PONDS. THE BENEFICIARIES ARE THE SMC.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT IS TO INCREASE ADOPTION OF VOLUNTARY WETLAND RESTORATION PRACTICES TO HELP ADDRESS WATER-RELATED ISSUES IN WISCONSIN'S AGRICULTURAL LANDSCAPES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT IS TO CREATE THE FRAMEWORK OF A NEW FUNCTIONAL ASSESSMENT TOOL THAT CAN BE USED TO EVALUATE WETLANDS FOR PERMITTING PURPOSES, ESTIMATE WETLAND MITIGATION NEEDS, ASSESS MITIGATION SITE POTENTIAL, ASSESS RESTORATION SITE FUNCTIONALITY, AND/OR MONITOR WETLANDS FOR CHANGE OVER TIME. SPECIFICALLY, TO ACCOMPLISH THIS TASK, WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL PARTNER WITH THE MINNESOTA BOARD OF WATER AND SOIL RESOURCES (BWSR) AS A SUB-AWARDEE TO PRODUCE THE PROTOTYPE FOR A NEW MINNESOTA AND WISCONSIN RAPID WETLAND ASSESSMENT METHODOLOGY AND ASSOCIATED CALCULATOR. THE PROJECT WILL ADVANCE THE MONITORING, ASSESSMENT, AND REGULATORY CORE ELEMENTS AND THE STRATEGIC GOAL OF PROTECTING WETLANDS AND WATER QUALITY. EXPECTED BENEFICIARIES ARE RESIDENTS OF WISCONSIN.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT IS TO FUND THE DEVELOPMENT OF ADDITIONAL TOOLS AND RESOURCES THAT CAN BE EXTRACTED FROM EXISTING MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT DATA AND TO GROW THE CAPACITY OF THE WETLAND MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT PROGRAM. SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A SUITE OF NEW TOOLS/PRODUCTS TO BE USED IN REGULATORY APPLICATIONS, FOR PUBLIC EDUCATION, AND FOR IMPROVED WETLAND MONITORING CONSISTENCY AS WELL AS AN UPDATED, PRIORITIZED PLAN FOR THE WI DNR WETLAND MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT PROGRAM TO UNDERTAKE IN THE NEAR FUTURE. . TASKS INCLUDE: FORMING AN ADVISORY TEAM TO GUIDE THE PRIORITIZATION OF THIS DATA DEEP-DIVE, WORK WITH LTE STAFF TO PRODUCE USEFUL PRODUCTS FROM THIS DATA, AND TO REFLECT ON THE WORK THAT HAS BEEN COMPLETED TO-DATE SO AS TO MORE CLEARLY PRIORITIZE FUTURE WETLAND PROGRAM EFFORTS. THE PROJECT WILL ADVANCE THE WETLAND MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT PROTOCOL AND REGULATORY CORE ELEMENTS AND THE STRATEGIC GOAL OF PROTECTING WETLANDS AND WATER QUALITY. E

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DEVELOP AN UPDATED LAC COURTE OREILLES TRIBAL WETLANDS PROGRAM PLAN FROM THE LAC COURTE OREILLES WETLANDS CONSERVATION PLAN (2000). THE WPP WILL BE SUBMITTED TO THE EPA FOR APPROVAL AND ACCOMPLISHED WITH FOUR OBJECTIVES. THE FIRST WILL BE FOR STAFF TO ATTEND WETLAND MEETINGS AND TRAININGS TO ENSURE QUALITY MONITORING OF INDICATORS WITH CURRENT SCIENTIFIC FINDINGS AND METHODOLOGIES. THE SECOND WILL BE CONDUCTING RAPID ASSESSMENTS FOR THE FIVE REFERENCE WETLANDS INDICATED IN THE WETLANDS CONSERVATION PLAN TO DETERMINE WETLAND CONDITION AND ANALYZE IF THERE ANY CHANGES IN EXTENT OR CONDITION. THE THIRD WILL BE TO CONDUCT EIGHT FLORISTIC QUALITY ASSESSMENTS IN THE FOUR WETLAND TYPES WHICH ARE FOUND ON THE RESERVATION. THE FINAL OBJECTIVE WILL BE MAPPING CURRENT WETLANDS WITHIN THE RESERVATION BOUNDARIES. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM WILL BE MEMBERS OF THE LAC COURTE OREILLES BAND OF LAKE SUPERIOR CHIPPEWA INDIANS.

THIS PROJECT IS FOR THE IDENTIFICATION AND EVALUATION OF ALTERNATE WETLAND ASSESSMENT METHODS.  THIS STUDY WILL LOOK AT WETLAND ASSESSMENT METHODS USED IN OTHER STATES AND TAKE A CRITICAL LOOK AT THE OHIO RAPID ASSESSMENT METHOD AND VEGETATION INDEX OF BIOLOGICAL INTEGRITY.  OHIO EPA (OEPA) WILL CONSIDER ALTERNATE, MORE COMPREHENSIVE METHODS FOR EVALUATING MITIGATION SITES TO DETERMINE IF OTHER METHODS MAY BE APPROPRIATE FOR WETLAND REGULATION IN OHIO.

WRIGHT STATE UNIVERSITY (WSU) WILL EVALUATE THE SOIL BULK DENSITY AS AN INDICATOR OF WETLAND SOIL CONDITION AND THE FEASIBILITY OF INCORPORATING THIS PARAMATER INTO A LEVEL 2 ('RAPID') WETLAND ASSESSMENT.  THE SAMPLING PROPOSED WILL CONFIRM THE SUITABILITY OF SOIL BULK DENSITY AS AN INDICATOR OF SOIL CONDITION, ASSIST IN EVALUATING THE EFFICACY OF OHIO RAPID ASSESSMENT METHOD (ORAM) SCORES ABILITY TO REFLECT SOIL CONDITION, AND EXPLORE THE OPPORTUNITY OF DEVELOPING A MODIFIED ORAM SCORE TO BETTER REPRESENT SOIL CONDITION BY INCLUSION OF SOIL BULK DENSITY.

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF WISCONSIN FOR WETLAND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE IDENTIFYING AND ASSESSING THE FLORISTIC QUALITY, COMMUNITY COMPOSITION, AND POTENTIAL ECOLOGICAL DISTURBANCE FACTORS OF MULTIPLE RARE AND UNIQUE WETLAND COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE.  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS THREE-FOLD: 1) TO GATHER ADDITIONAL BASELINE VEGETATIVE QUALITY DATA ON RARE AND HIGH-QUALITY WETLAND COMMUNITIES, 2) TO ESTABLISH A THRESHOLD OR BENCHMARK CONDITION FOR THESE RARE COMMUNITIES, AND 3) TO ESTABLISH A NETWORK OF RARE WETLAND COMMUNITIES THAT CAN BE TRACKED, MANAGED, AND PROTECTED INTO THE FUTURE.

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF WISCONSIN FOR WETLAND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL INVESTIGATE THE FEASIBILITY OF A RAPID FLORISTIC QUALITY ASSESSMENT TOOL FOR USE BY THE DEPARTMENT'S FIELD STAFF, THAT DOES NOT REQUIRE AN EXPERT BOTANIST TO CONDUCT THE ASSESSMENT.  IN ADDITION, THE DEPARTMENT WILL BEGIN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A WISCONSIN-SPECIFIC LEVEL 2 RAPID FLORISTIC QUALITY ASSESSMENT PROTOCOL.

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE VILLAGE OF PLOVER IN WISCONSIN FOR WETLAND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THE EARLY SUCCESSES OF AN INTEGRATED WATERSHED MANAGEMENT PROJECT IN CENTRAL WISCONSIN'S LITTLE PLOVER RIVER (LPR) WATERSHED AND TO SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT-SUPPORTED, WATERSHED-BASED, WETLANDS CONSERVATION INITIATIVES IN THE REGION. THE PROJECT EMPLOYS THE THREE KEY APPROACHES EPA RECOGNIZES AS IMPORTANT TO WETLAND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT: OUTREACH AND EDUCATION, PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS, AND AGENCY COORDINATION.

LEWIS AND CLARK COLLEGE WILL DEVELOP AND REFINE A METHODOLOGY FOR DETECTING AND CATALOGUING EPHEMERAL FORESTED WETLANDS THAT ARE TYPICALLY MISSED USING TRADITIONAL METHODS.  THE WORK WILL ALSO PROVIDE AN ASSESSMENT OF EPHEMERAL FOREST WETLAND QUALITY IN SOUTHERN ILLINOIS.

THIS GRANT AGREEMENT PROVIDES FUNDING TO THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA TO CREATE A REMOTE SENSING-BASED SYSTEM WHICH WILL ALLOW FOR HIGH FREQUENCY MONITORING OF THE DYNAMICS OF WATER, WETLANDS, AND WETLAND VEGETATION IN MINNESOTA.  THIS SYSTEM WOULD USE THE VAST ARCHIVES OF SATELLITE AND AERIAL IMAGERY IN THE FREE-TO-USE GOOGLE EARTH ENGINE ANALYSIS ENVIRONMENT, COMBINED WITH PURPOSE-BUILT CUSTOM CODE TO ALLOW WETLAND AND OTHER NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS TO IDENTIFY LANDSCAPE CHANGES WITHIN WEEKS AFTER OCCURRENCE, AND MONITOR THOSE CHANGES INTO THE FUTURE.

THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT, GREAT LAKES, AND ENERGY (MDEGLE)'S WETLAND PROGRAM IS TO PROTECT, MANAGE, AND RESTORE MICHIGAN'S WETLANDS IN ORDER TO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC BENEFITS DEFINED BY THE LEGISLATURE IN THE WETLANDS PROTECTION LAW. THE MDEGLE USES SEVERAL LONG TERM STRATEGIES TO REACH THIS GOAL, INCLUDING:  - MAINTAINING A SHORT-TERM GOAL OF ACHIEVING NO NET LOSS OF WETLAND ACREAGE, FUNCTION, AND PUBLIC VALUE AND A LONG-TERM GOAL OF INCREASING THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF MICHIGAN'S WETLANDS THROUGH RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT.  - PROTECTING MICHIGAN'S REMAINING WETLANDS THROUGH IMPLEMENTATION OF AN EFFECTIVE AND EFFICIENT REGULATORY PROGRAM AND MAINTAINING ADMINISTRATION OF SECTION 404 OF THE FEDERAL CLEAN WATER ACT.  - ASSESSING AND MONITORING THE QUALITY AND QUANTITY OF MICHIGAN'S WETLANDS TO IMPROVE WETLAND PROTECTION, MANAGEMENT, AND RESTORATION.  - WORKING WITH PARTNERS TO IDENTIFY AND DEVELOP METHODS TO IMPROVE PROTECTION, MANAGEMENT AN

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE LEECH LAKE BAND OF OJIBWE FOR THEIR TRIBAL WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THEIR PREVIOUS PLAN AND DETERMINE AN APPROPRIATE STRATEGY FOR MAPPING WETLANDS ACROSS THREE HYDROLOGIC UNIT CODE 8 WATERSHEDS.  TEN TRIBAL STAFF WILL BE TRAINED IN WETLAND DELINEATION TO INCREASE TRIBAL TECHNICAL CAPACITY.  THE PROJECT EMPLOYS THE THREE KEY APPROACHES EPA RECOGNIZES AS IMPORTANT TO WETLAND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT: OUTREACH AND EDUCATION, PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS, AND AGENCY COORDINATION.

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE FOREST COUNTY POTAWATOMI COMMUNITY FOR THEIR TRIBAL WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL UPDATE THEIR PREVIOUS PLAN AND CREATE A REFERENCE WETLANDS NETWORK TO DEFINE REFERENCE STANDARD WETLANDS.

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO MINNESOTA BOARD OF WATER AND SOIL RESOURCES TO UNDERTAKE THE EFFORTS ASSOCIATED WITH PREPARING A PACKAGE FOR ASSUMING THE CLEAN WATER ACT SECTION 404 PROGRAM.  THIS WORK WILL BUILD ON A PREVIOUSLY CONDUCTED FEASIBILITY STUDY FOR 404 ASSUMPTION CONDUCTED BY THE STATE OF MINNESOTA.

MINNESOTA BOARD OF WATER AND SOIL RESOURCES WILL EXPAND WORK BY COLLECTING VEGETATIVE QUALITY DATA ON DEPRESSIONAL MITIGATION WETLANDS IN SOUTHERN MINNESOTA.  THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A STATUS OF WETLAND MITIGATION CONDITION TO COMPARE TO STATEWIDE AMBIENT MONITORING RESULTS CONDUCTED BY OTHER AGENCIES IN THE STATE AS WELL AS ESTABLISH A BASELINE DATA FOR FUTURE TRENDS ANALYSIS.

MINNESOTA BOARD OF WATER AND SOIL RESOURCES WILL PRODUCE A COMPENSATION PLANNING FRAMEWORK (CPF) FOR THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER HEADWATERS WATERSHED IN NORTH CENTRAL MINNESOTA.  THE CPF WILL ENABLE THE IDENTIFICATION AND PRIORITIZATION OF WETLAND RESTORATION OPPORTUNITIES AT THE CATCHMENT SCALE.

TO ESTABLISH AND IMPLEMENT AN IMPROVED, LONG-TERM MONITORING NETWORK TO DOCUMENT PRE-INVASION WETLAND HYDROLOGY, POST EMERALD ASH BORER IMPACTS TO HELP PREDICT LONG-TERM CHANGES, AND VALIDATE MITIGATIONS TO REPLACE BLACK ASH FUNCTIONS USING REPLACEMENT TREES. THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A TECHNICAL REPORT ON THE EFFECTS OF TREE SPECIES SAP-FLOW HYDROLOGY OF UNDERSTUDIES ECOSYSTEMS TO INFORM AND GUIDE MANAGEMENT, PROVIDE A LIST OF SPECIES CONTAINING SAP-FLOW FUNCTIONALITY AND TRADITIONAL USES TO INFORM CULTURAL ADAPTATION, PROVIDE THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY WITH A STORY MAP INCLUDING PROJECT INFORMATION, PHOTOS, OTHER MEDIA TO PROMOTE THE WETLAND PROGRAM'S EFFORTS AS LISTED IN THE WETLANDS PROGRAM PLAN.

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF WISCONSIN FOR WETLAND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT.  SPECIFICALLY, TO INVESTIGATE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN HYDROLOGY AND FLORISTIC QUALITY FOR SELECTED PLANT COMMUNITIES.  ALSO, FOR A 404 ASSUMPTION FEASIBILITY STUDY.

THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN AN UPDATED STOCKBRIDGE-MUNSEE COMMUNITY WETLAND PROGRAM WITH AN IMPROVED MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT STRATEGY THAT INCLUDES WETLAND CONDITION ASSESSMENT.  CONDITION ASSESSMENTS WILL BE COMPLETED ON 50 TO 75 WETLANDS TO REFINE METHODOLOGY, ESTABLISH BASELINE CONDITIONS, AND DEFINE A DISTURBANCE GRADIENT.  ADDITIONALLY, THE TRIBE WILL COMPLETE A LANDSCAPE-LEVEL ASSESSMENT OF WETLAND STRESSORS TO HELP IDENTIFY THREATS AND PRIORITIZE PROTECTION EFFORTS.

THIS PROJECT IS THE THIRD PHASE OF A WETLAND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN-EXTENSION(UWEX) AND THE WISCONSIN WETLAND ASSOCIATION. THE BROADER COLLABORATION SEEKS TO INCREASE VOLUNTARY WETLAND PROTECTION AND RESTORATION ACROSS WISCONSIN BY HELPING KEY AUDIENCES ENGAGE IN WETLAND PLANNING, RESEARCH, AND RESTORATION.

THIS PROJECT WILL HELP INFORM WHAT REQUIREMENTS AND POLICIES ARE NECESSARY TO PROTECT WETLAND FROM POTENTIAL ADVERSE IMPACTS OF GROUNDWATER APPROPRIATION OR DIVERSIONS AS WELL AS DETERMINING REQUIREMENTS NECESSARY TO ENSURE LONG-TERM WETLAND RESTORATION SUCCESS.

THE RED LAKE BAND OF THE CHIPPEWA INDIANS PLAN TO USE THIS GRANT TO MONITOR AND PROTECT THEIR WETLANDS. THIS INCLUDES DEVELOPING: AN EXTENSIVE WETLAND INVENTORY, A WETLAND MONITORING STRATEGY, AND A DRAFT SHORELINE ORDINANCE.

THROUGH ITS TWO RELATED COMPONENTS, THIS 2-YEAR PROJECT WILL TAKE STRATEGIC STEPS TO MOVE FORWARD CRITICAL COMPONENTS OF WISCONSIN'S WETLAND PROGRAM USING CONDITION AND FUNCTION ASSESSMENT METHODS DEVELOPED IN PREVIOUS WETLAND GRANT PROJECTS. COMPONENT ONE INVOLVES EVALUATING COMPLETED MITIGATION PROJECTS TO ASCERTAIN THEIR LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY AND ASSESS THE OVERALL EFFICACY OF THE COMPENSATORY WETLAND MITIGATION PROGRAM IN WISCONSIN. COMPONENT TWO INVOLVES PILOT PROJECTS IN TWO 10-DIGIT WISCONSIN WATERSHEDS TO INCORPORATE LEVEL 1, 2 AND 3 WETLAND ASSESSMENT SURVEYS INTO WISCONSIN'S TARGETED WATERSHED ASSESSMENT MONITORING PROGRAM.

THE OHIO ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (OEPA) WILL FOCUS ITS EFFORTS ON DEVELOPING A CERTIFICATION PROGRAM FOR WATER QUALITY PROFESSIONALS IN OHIO. THIS PROGRAM WILL TRAIN INDIVIDUALS TO ACCURATELY CONDUCT STREAM AND WETLAND ASSESSMENTS ASSOCIATED WITH 401 CERTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS. ALSO, OEPA WILL DEVELOP A STRATEGIC PLAN TO ASSESS AND ADDRESS FAILED STREAM AND WETLAND MITIGATION SITES IN OHIO. THE GRANT'S ACTIVITIES WILL PRIORITIZE WORK, DEVELOP EFFECTIVE AND RAPID ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES, AND A COMPREHENSIVE SITE LIST OF WHERE MITIGATION GOALS HAVE NOT BEEN MET.

THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD, REFINE, AND ADVANCE THE PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT OF WETLANDS IN MICHIGAN BY ADDRESSING THE CORE ELEMENT FRAMEWORK ACTIONS:  (1) CONSIDER WILDLIFE HABITAT AND OTHER OBJECTIVES FOR PROTECTION SITES, (2) PROVIDE GUIDANCE ON APPROPRIATE RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES, (3) ESTABLISH PARTNERSHIPS TO LEVERAGE ADDITIONAL PROTECTION, (4)  DEVELOP REGULATIONS AND RULES (GUIDANCE) TO IMPLEMENT STATE STATUTES (5) DEVELOP PROCEDURES FOR REVIEWING AND RESPONDING TO APPLICATIONS, (6) ENSURE IMPACT ASSESSMENTS AND MITIGATION LEAD TO REPLACEMENT OF AQUATIC RESOURCES WITH SIMILAR STRUCTURAL, FUNCTIONAL OR CONDITION ATTRIBUTES, AND (7) PERFORM PUBLIC EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ABOUT WETLAND PROTECTION.

THIS ACTION PROVIDES FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $136,843 TO TENNESSEE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT & CONSERVATION TO BUILD, REFINE AND PROVIDE EDUCATION ON ECOLOGICAL ENDPOINTS OF STREAMS AND WETLANDS.  ECOLOGICAL ENDPOINTS ARE THE MEASURES OF SUCCESS USED TO EVALUATE ENVIRONMENTAL RESUTLS FOR COMPENSATORY MITIGATION AND BUILD A FOUNDATION FOR REGULATORY MANAGEMENT, MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT PROGRAMS.

THIS ACTION PROVIDES FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $205,831 TO FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION TO DEVELOP A MOBILE APPLICATION OF THE CHAPTER 62-340, F.A.C. DATA FORM. THE FORM IS USED TO RECORD ALL RELEVANT INFORMATION FOR MAKING DETERMINATIONS REGARDING WETLAND AND OTHER SURFACE WATERS IN FLORIDA FOR REGULATORY PURPOSES. THE PROJECT FOCUSES ON ASSISTANCE TO PROTECT, MANAGE, AND RESTORE WETLANDS AND SUPPORTS THE ABILITY TO DEMONSTRATE ENVIRONMENTAL OUTCOMES.

THIS ACTION PROVIDES FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $64,713 TO NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY TO UPDATE THE NORTH CAROLINA WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN (WPP) APPROVED IN 2015 AND REVISE THE COMMON WETLAND PLANTS OF NORTH CAROLINA GUIDE PUBLISHED IN 1997 TO IMPROVE WETLANDS PROJECTS AND AWARENESS AND IMPROVEMENT COMMUNICATION AND COLLABORATION OF WETLANDS PRIORITIES.

THIS PROPOSAL IS FOR THE OVERALL SUPPORT OF WETLAND PROGRAMS IN THE NORTHEAST VIA THE NEW ENGLAND BIOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT OF WETLANDS WORK GROUP (NEBAWWG). THE GOALS OF THIS WORK GROUP INCLUDE: 1) DEVELOP, IMPROVE AND/OR REFINE SCIENTIFICALLY VALID WETLANDS MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT METHODS, AND 2) FURTHER DEVELOP AND INSTITUTIONALIZE THE WETLANDS BIOMONITORING PROGRAMS OF NORTHEAST STATES. SPECIFICALLY, IN THIS PROPOSAL, NEW ENGLAND INTERSTATE WATER POLLUTION CONTROL COMMISSION (NEIWPCC) WILL COORDINATE NEBAWWG MEETINGS, FACILITATE COMMUNICATION, LEARNING, AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT THROUGHOUT THE WORK GROUP; AND SUPPORT THE FORMATION, DRAFTING AND ENACTION OF A MISSION STATEMENT AND STRATEGIC PLAN THAT WILL DIRECT WORKGROUP ACTIVITIES AND ESTABLISH BENCHMARKS FOR SUCCESS TIED TO STATE LEVEL WETLAND MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT PROGRAMS.

THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE PUBLICS UNDERSTANDING OF VERMONT'S WETLANDS TO RESTORE AND PROTECT OUR AQUATIC HABITAT BY COLLECTING WETLAND CONDITION DATA AND IMPROVE WETLAND MAPPING IN VERMONT. TASKS TO BE ACCOMPLISHED INCLUDE COLLECTING AND REPORTING ON WETLAND DATA WITH THE WATER QUALITY PROGRAMS' BASIN ROTATION SCHEDULE, COLLECTING ADDITIONAL YEARS OF WETLAND SOLAR FIELD DATA, AND DEVELOPING IMPROVED METHODOLOGIES FOR EDITING WETLAND MAPS WITH NEW INFORMATION. FINAL PRODUCTS WILL BE REPORTS OF DATA ANALYSIS, PUBLIC-FRIENDLY MAP TOOLS, PRESENTATIONS, AND ONLINE WEBINAR EDUCATIONAL TOOLS. THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE THE ACCURACY OF RECORDS IN NHB'S DATABASE TO BETTER INFORM ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEWS, MITIGATION, AND CONSERVATION, AND TO IMPROVE FLORISTIC QUALITY ASSESSMENT (FQA) PERFORMANCE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE (NH). THE NEW HAMPSHIRE NATURAL HERITAGE BUREAU (NHB) WILL ACCOMPLISH THIS BY DOCUMENTING NEW HIGH PRIORITY WETLANDS IN THE FIELD AND BY SURVEYING AND REEVALUATING THE ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY OF KNOWN EXEMPLARY WETLANDS WITH OUTDATED RECORDS USING THE LATEST DATA STANDARDS AND CONDITION ASSESSMENT METHOD (ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY ASSESSMENT [EIA]). RECENTLY DEVELOPED FQA REFERENCE THRESHOLDS WILL BE REFINED FOR UNDER-SAMPLED WETLAND SYSTEM TYPES IN NH USING VEGETATION PLOT DATA COLLECTED DURING FIELD SURVEYS. WETLAND SCIENTISTS AND ENVIRONMENTAL PERMIT REVIEW STAFF WILL USE THE DATA TO MORE EFFECTIVELY INFORM CONSERVATION, AND TO DEVELOP SPECIFIC WETLAND SYSTEM PERFORMANCE CRITERIA FOR MONITORING WETLAND MITIGATION AND RESTORATION PROJECTS. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT WETLANDS FROM DEGRADATION OR DESTRUCTION THROUGH FIELD MAPPING, AND IDENTIFYING CONNECTED RIPARIAN NETWORKS. THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT AN EFFECTIVE WETLANDS MONITORING STRATEGY, IMPLEMENT A SUSTAINABLE PROGRAM, AND CLEARLY AND CONSISTENCY DEFINE WETLAND PROTECTION AND RESTORATION EFFORTS AND PROTECTION GOALS IN THE STATE OF MAINE.

PER YOUR APPLICATION REQUEST DATED JULY 15, 2021, THIS GRANT AGREEMENT IS BEING AWARDED FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $250,000 TO UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS. UMASS WILL USE UNOCCUPIED AERIAL SYSTEMS (UAS) TECHNOLOGY TO ASSESS VULNERABILITY TO FLOODING AND ASSESS THE PHYSICAL AND BIOLOGICAL CONDITION OF SALT MARSHES ACROSS MASSACHUSETTS. THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE: (1) HIGH-RESOLUTION MAPPING OF VEGETATION, WATER FEATURES, AND BARE GROUND, (2) UNVEGETATED TO VEGETATED RATIOS CALCULATED AT VARIOUS RESOLUTIONS, (3) HIGH-RESOLUTION DIGITAL ELEVATION MODELS, (4) IDENTIFICATION AND MAPPING OF ACTIVE EROSION AND MARSH DIEBACK, AND (5) PROBABILITY OF INUNDATION MAPS TO REPRESENT VULNERABILITY OF HIGH MARSH TO DROWNING DUE TO SEA LEVEL RISE (SLR). THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO HELP REGULATORY AGENCIES AND WETLAND PROGRAM MANAGERS IDENTIFY AND PROTECT SALT MARSHES THAT ARE MOST VULNERABLE TO SLR AND OTHER THREATS.

THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT BY THE MAINE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE CONSERVATION AND FORESTRY (MEDOACF) IS TO (1) DEVELOP A MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT STRATEGY CONSISTENT WITH ELEMENTS OF A STATE WATER MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT PROGRAM FOR WETLANDS; (2) IMPLEMENT A SUSTAINABLE MONITORING PROGRAM CONSISTENT WITH THE WETLANDS MONITORING STRATEGY (3) CLEARLY AND CONSISTENTLY DEFINE RESTORATION AND PROTECTION GOALS THROUGHOUT THE STATE; (4) PROTECT WETLANDS FROM DEGRADATION OR DESTRUCTION.  METHODS FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE PLANNING AND COLLABORATION, CONDUCTING REPRESENTATIONAL ANALYSIS, DEVELOPING RANDOM FOREST MACHINE LEARNING MODELS, EVALUATING COMPUTATIONAL RESULTS TO DEVELOP FIELD WORK PLANS, DATA COLLECTION AND PROCESSING, GIS MAPPING, AND DATA DISSEMINATION.  INITIAL AWARD.

THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE CONNECTICUT'S TIDAL WETLANDS RESILIENCY TO SEA LEVEL RISE (SLR), AND IMPROVE CONNECTICUT'S OVERALL WETLAND CONDITION THROUGH THE ASSESSMENT AND DEVELOPMENT OF REGULATORY MECHANISMS AND PLANNING STRATEGIES. TASKS INCLUDE: (1) SYNTHESIZE EXISTING, AND IDENTIFY GAPS IN, SLR AFFECTING TIDAL WETLANDS DATA; (2) ANALYZE EXISTING CONNECTICUT WETLAND REGULATORY PROGRAMS AND SURVEY OTHER STATE PROGRAMS WHICH ADDRESS WETLANDS SUSTAINABILITY TO SLR; (3) ESTABLISH A TIDAL WETLAND MIGRATION PROTECTION POLICY PROPOSAL WORK GROUP; AND (4) PREPARE TIDAL WETLAND MIGRATION PROTECTION POLICY PROPOSALS.   INITIAL AWARD.

NEW ENGLAND INTERSTATE WATER POLLUTION CONTROL COMMISSION (NEIWPCC) WILL PROVIDE LOGISTICAL FACILITATION OF AND SUPPORT FOR THE NEW ENGLAND BIOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT WETLAND WORK GROUP (NEBAWWG) BY PROVIDING OVERALL SUPPORT FOR WETLAND PROGRAMS TO ESTABLISH, IMPROVE, AND/OR REFINE WETLANDS MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT METHODS, INCLUDING BIOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT.  NEIWPCC WILL HOLD A 2 DAY MEETING TO COLLABORATE WITH NEBAWWG MEMBERS TO DETERMINE HIGHEST PRIORITY TOPICS AND ACTIVITIES AND ASSEMBLE A REVIEW AND PLANNING TEAM TO DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE REGIONAL REPORT THAT AMASSES NORTHEAST STATES MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT DATA TO IDENTIFY COMMONALITIES.  NEIWPCC MAY PARTNER WITH NATURESERVE TO PERFORM DATA ANALYSIS AND REPORT DEVELOPMENT WITH REVIEW AND GUIDANCE PROVIDED BY NEBAWWG MEMBERS.

THE RHODE ISLAND DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT, IN COLLABORATION WITH THE RHODE ISLAND COASTAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT COUNCIL, WILL CARRY OUT A MULTI-YEAR PROJECT THAT WILL BUILD RHODE ISLAND WETLAND PROGRAM CAPACITY BY STRENGTHENING THE TECHNICAL BASIS OF A REFERENCE CONDITION GRADIENT BEING DEVELOPED FOR SALT MARSHES THROUGH MONITORING (MARSHRAM) AND DEVELOPING A PROGRAM FOR MAPPING VERNAL POOLS. THE TASKS OF THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE (1) THE BUILD-OUT OF A MORE RIGOROUS AND COMPLETE SALT MARSH CONDITION GRADIENT, AND (2) DEVELOPMENT AND DEMONSTRATION OF A PROGRAM TO MAP AND VERIFY THE LOCATION OF VERNAL POOLS.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE PROTECTION OF RARE PLANTS AND SIGNIFICANT NATURAL COMMUNITIES THROUGH THE VERMONT WETLAND RULES BY INTEGRATION OF RARE PLANT AND NATURAL COMMUNITY INVENTORY, MONITORING, AND DATA SHARING WITH THE VERMONT WETLANDS OFFICE. THE VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT, NATURAL HERITAGE INVENTORY (VNHI) WILL MONITOR, INVENTORY AND MAP VERMONT'S RARE, THREATENED AND ENDANGERED WETLAND PLANTS AND SIGNIFICANT NATURAL COMMUNITIES SO THEY ARE AVAILABLE FOR CONSERVATION PLANNING AND REGULATORY REVIEW. TASKS WILL INCLUDE:1) DEVELOPING A DETAILED WORK PLAN AND A QUALITY ASSURANCE PROJECT PLAN (QAPP) TO EFFECTIVELY AND EFFICIENTLY COMPLETE THE PROJECT. 2) SELECTING INVENTORY SITES FOCUSING ON VERMONT WETLANDS PROGRAM (VWP) PRIORITIES, UNDER SAMPLED WETLAND NATURAL COMMUNITY TYPES AS DETERMINED BY THE VERMONT CONSERVATION DESIGN PROJECT, AND HIGH PRIORITY RARE WETLAND PLANTS. LANDOWNERS WILL BE IDENTIFIED AND CONTACTED FOR PERMISSION TO ACCESS SELECTED SIT

THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO ADVANCE THE SCIENCE OF WETLAND MONITORING AND TO ASSESS THE CONDITION OF VERMONT'S WETLANDS AT A LOCAL AND NATIONAL SCALE. THE VERMONT DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION WILL COMPLETE THE LEVEL THREE ECOLOGICAL AND WATER QUALITY MONITORING AND RAPID ASSESSMENT OF SITES BASED ON THE WATER QUALITY ROTATIONAL BASIN SCHEDULE AND COMPLETE THE 2021 NATIONAL AQUATIC WETLAND RESOURCE SURVEY. WORK TO BE ACCOMPLISHED INCLUDES STATEWIDE MONITORING OF WETLAND WATER QUALITY, FLORA, SOILS, FUNCTIONS, AND SPATIAL EXTENT ON A BASIN BY BASIN EFFORT. WETLAND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WILL INVOLVE DOCUMENTING EACH SITE'S PHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS, FUNCTION AND CONDITION (PRE-AND POST RESTORATION) FOR IMPROVED FUTURE EFFORTS.

THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE QUALITY AND QUANTITY OF VERMONT WETLANDS BY INCREASING WETLAND RESTORATION EFFORTS AND SUCCESS ON PREVIOUSLY DISTURBED SITES. THE WORK WILL FOCUS ON ASSESSING THE VARIABILITY OF SOIL PROPERTIES IN VERMONT WETLANDS THAT INFLUENCE PHOSPHORUS RETENTION CAPACITY, AND TO RECOGNIZE WHICH SOIL PROPERTIES CAN PREDICT PHOSPHORUS RETENTION POTENTIAL.  THIS DATA, IN ADDITION TO OTHER LANDSCAPE DATA COLLECTED WILL PROVIDE IMPORTANT INFORMATION FOR SELECTION OF RESTORATION SITES. TASKS TO BE ACCOMPLISHED INCLUDE WETLAND RESTORATION PROGRAM INTEGRATION WITH OTHER EASEMENT/CONSERVATION PROGRAMS, COLLECTING DATA ON RESTORED SITES, AND DEVELOPING AN IN LIEU FEE STATE PROGRAM PROTOCOL.  FINAL PRODUCTS WILL BE REPORTS OF DATA ANALYSIS, TEMPLATE EASEMENT LANGUAGE, PRESENTATION AND IN LIEU FEE STATE PROTOCOL.

THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN NEW WETLAND MAPPING METHODOLOGY FOR THE STATE OF VERMONT.  THE OTTER CREEK SUBBASIN IS OVERTAXED WITH PHOSPHORUS POLLUTION STEMMING PRIMARILY FROM AGRICULTURE.  UNDERSTANDING THE SPATIAL EXTENT OF WETLANDS IN THIS BASIN IS CRUCIAL TO MANAGING WATER QUALITY.  THE MAIN TASKS ARE TO PRODUCE HIGH QUALITY NATIONAL WETLANDS INVENTORY (NWI) AND LEVEL MAPPING OF THE OTTER CREEK SUBBASIN, FIELD-REVIEW THE ACCURACY OF THE MAPPING, AND CREATE OUTREACH MATERIALS FOR LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES. THE UPDATED MAPS WILL BE USED BY ENTITIES CURRENTLY CREATING CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION MODELING IN THE LAKE CHAMPLAIN BASIN

PER YOUR APPLICATION REQUEST DATED MAY 24, 2019, THIS GRANT AGREEMENT IS BEING AWARDED FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF 35,185 TO THE EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF ENERGY & ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS.  THESE FUNDS WILL ASSIST THE MASSACHUSETTS OFFICE OF COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT (CZM) WITH CONDUCTING ACTIVITIES TO SUPPORT THEIR PROGRAMMATIC MISSION TO ASSESS, MANAGE, PROTECT, AND RESTORE COASTAL WETLANDS. MASSACHUSETTS CZM WILL: (1) ESTABLISH A ROBUST TIME SERIES OF DATA TO DETECT AND INTERPRET TRENDS IN MARSH MICROHABITATS; (2) DEVELOP AN INNOVATIVE DATA VIEWER TO PROVIDE OUTREACH ON A FORTHCOMING SALT MARSH VULNERABILITY METRIC APPLIED ACROSS MASSACHUSETTS MARSHES, WITH AN ASSOCIATED FRAMEWORK AND DATA COLLECTION PROTOCOL FOR ASSESSING SEDIMENT DYNAMICS; AND (3) CONDUCT A REVIEW OF THE SCIENCE, POLICY, AND PRACTICE OF DREDGING TO INFORM BEST PRACTICES FOR MAINTAINING THE AVAILABILITY OF SEDIMENTS FOR SALT MARSHES. THESE ACTIONS WILL SUPPORT CZM AND PARTNER EFFORTS TO CONSERVE THE QUALITY AND QUANTITY

THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO ADVANCE THE SCIENCE OF WETLAND MONITORING AND TO ASSESS THE THE CONDITION OF VERMONT'S WETLANDS, IMPROVE STATE REGULATIONS THROUGH RULEMAKING, AND ENHANCE WETLAND RESTORATION EFFORTS.  WORK TO BE ACCOMPLISHED INCLUDES MONITORING OF WETLAND WATER QUALITY, FLORA, SOILS, FUNCTIONS, AND SPATIAL EXTENT ON A BASIN BY BASIN EFFORT; DOCUMENTING EACH SITES PHYSICAL CHARACTERICS, FUNCTION AND CONDITION (PRE-AND POST) FOR IMPROVED FUTURE EFFORTS RELATED TO WETLAND RESTORATION; ADDING CLARIFYING LANGUAGE IN THE VERMONT WETLAND RULES FOR GREATER TRANSPARENCY AND STREAMLINING; AND CREATING A STATEWIDE WETLAND RESTORATION STRATEGY.

THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN NEW WETLAND MAPPING METHODOLOGY FOR THE STATE OF VERMONT.  THE MISSISQUOI SUBBASIN IS OVERTAXED WITH PHOSPHORUS POLLUTION STEMMING PRIMARILY FROM AGRICULTURE.  UNDERSTANDING THE SPATIAL EXTENT OF WETLANDS IN THIS BASIN IS CRUCIAL TO MANAGING WATER QUALITY.  THE MAIN TASKS ARE TO PRODUCE HIGH QUALITY NATIONAL WETLANDS INVENTORY AND LEVEL MAPPING OF THE MISSISQUOI SUBBASIN, FIELD-REVIEW THE ACCURACY OF THE MAPPING, AND CREATE OUTREACH MATERIALS FOR LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES. THE UPDATED MAPS WILL BE USED BY ENTITIES CURRENTLY CREATING CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION MODELING IN THE LAKE CHAMPLAIN BASIN.

PER YOUR APPLICATION REQUEST DATED MAY 1, 2017, THIS GRANT AGREEMENT AWARDS FEDERAL FINDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $73,803 TO THE EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS  TO SUPPORT THE FIVE (5) YEAR MASSACHUSETTS WETLAND PROGRAM PLAN (WPP) 2013-2017.

THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO SUPPORT THE RECIPIENT ACCOMPLISH A PUBLIC PURPOSE BY SUPPORTING ACTIVITIES AUTHORIZED BY THE CLEAN WATER ACT SECTION 104 (B)(3) WHICH WILL HELP THE STATE OF MASSACHUSETTS AND OTHER NEW ENGLAND STATES PROTECT AND MANAGE WETLAND RESOURCES BY IMPROVING MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT EFFORTS.. THE PROJECT SEEKS TO DEVELOP NEW TECHNIQUES FOR ASSESSING SALT MARSH CONDITIONS AND IMPROVING CONSERVATION ASSESSMENT AND PRIORITIZATION SYSTEM (CAPS) METRICS AND ITS SALT MARSH ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY MODEL.   INITIAL AWARD

THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE (1) DEVELOP A MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT STRATEGY CONSISTENT WITH ELEMENTS OF A STATE WATER MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT PROGRAM; (2) IMPLEMENT A SUSTAINABLE MONITORING PROGRAM CONSISTENT WITH THE WETLANDS MONITORING STRATEGY; (3) CONTINUE TO CONSISTENTLY DEFINE RESTORATION AND PROTECTION GOALS THROUGHOUT THE STATE; (4) PROTECT WETLANDS FROM DEGRADATION OR DESTRUCTION.  INITIAL AWARD.

THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO SUPPORT THE NEW HAMPSHIRE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES (NHDES) CORE ELEMENTS IN THEIR WETLAND PROTECTION PLAN (REGULATION AND ENFORCEMENT, RESTORATION AND PROTECTION, MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT AND EDUCATION AND OUTREACH). THE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE 1)  DEVELOPING NEW INTERNAL PROTOCOLS FOR PERMIT REVIEWERS FOR TRACKING AND REPORTING WETLAND AND STREAM IMPACTS; 2) DEVELOPING A DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AND PERFORM A COMPHRENSIVE GEOSPATIAL ANALYSIS TO EVALUATE THE ECOLOGICAL PERFORMANCE OF THE IN-LIEU FEE PROGRAM'S MITIGATION SITES; AND 3) RESURVEYING WETLANDS OF HIGH ECOLOGICAL VALUE WITH OUTDATED RECORDS TO VERIFY THE CONDITION OF THESE PRIORITY WETLANDS USING ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY ASSESSMENT METHOD AND FLORISTIC QUALITY ASSESSMENT.

THE PROJECT SEEKS TO DEVELOP NEW TECHNIQUES FOR ASSESSING SALT MARSH CONDITIONS AND IMPROVING CONSERVATION ASSESSMENT AND PRIORITIZATION SYSTEM (CAPS) METRICS AND ITS SALT MARSH ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY MODEL. UMASS AMHERST WILL USE UNMANNED AERIAL SYSTEMS (UAS) TO COLLECT DATA AT CRITICAL TIMES IN THE TIDE CYCLE AND TEST THE POTENTIAL OF USING VARIOUS SENSORS TO ASSESS VEGETATION HEALTH/STRESS, FLOODING DYNAMICS, AND PHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF SALT MARSHES. TASKS INCLUDE: 1) SELECTION OF SALT MARSH STUDY SITES, 2) GROUND DATA COLLECTION FOR TRAINING AND VALIDATING UAS-BASED MODELS, 3) USE OF UAS TECHNOLOGY (E.G. RGB, REDEDGE, NIR & SWIR) TO COLLECT DATA TO MAP AND ASSESS SALT MARSHES, 4) ANALYZE UAS DATA TO MAP SALT MARSHES AND IDENTIFY AREAS OF STRESSED VEGETATION, EROSION, MARSH DIEBACK, AND INAPPROPRIATE FLOODING, 5) PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND REPORT WRITING.
